From ed at alcpress.com  Tue May  1 06:23:02 2007
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Tue, 01 May 2007 06:23:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] dnscache suddenly stoped working
In-Reply-To: <4636CD94.2020302@acm.org>
References: <4636CD94.2020302@acm.org>
Message-ID: <46373F36.8010508@alcpress.com>

Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> Well it appears it stopped working suddenly.  These dnscache servers 
> have been running for a really long time.  Suddenly this week-end it 
> appears they stopped replying to (or answering) queries.  In fact I 
> can't even get DNS services while logged in to the hosts.
> 
> I set up the servers several years ago but now only provide support on a 
> part-time/as-needed basis so I only have the story second hand.
> 
> We're using dnscache because it's small, fast and lets us provide access 
> to 'The Inclusive Internet'.
> 
> I checked /etc/dnsroots.global and though they differ from the results 
> of a  "dig @m.root-servers.net. ns ." there are enough common IPs to 
> make the look-ups work I would think.
> 
> Any suggestions?  Ed Sawicki?  :-)

I'm here, Rod. I don't read this list every day.
Check to see if the daemons (supervise, dnscache, etc.)
are running. Then check to see if dnscache is bound
to the usual ports. You should see something similar to
this if you use netstat:

tcp        0      0 1.2.3.4:53              0.0.0.0:* 
LISTEN      29000/dnscache
udp        0      0 1.2.3.4:53              0.0.0.0:* 
             29000/dnscache

You can also use: lsof -n|grep dnscache

If dnscache is not bound to a port, the usual cause
is a conflict. The netstat or lsof output will show
you this. Perhaps someone loaded a DNS authority
server, like BIND, on the box.

Ed

> 
> 
> TIA,
> Rod

On 4/30/07, John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
>
> <snip>
> Booting to recovery mode revealed that it goes into a continuous
> attempt to load /dev/md3, even though it was deleted. It doesn't show
> up in cat /proc/mdstat, anyway. So I used the rescue cd again, and
> decided to reformat the partitions that had been used for /dev/md3. As
> it was running along, suddenly a black screen again. And again, over
> and over. Every time I try to format a partition I get a power failure.
> Now I'm wondering if the 380 watt power supply is adequate. At least
> one thing is sure -- there is no point in trying to fix the partitions
> until I get the power supply stable.
>

I'd wager a _good_ 380 Watt power supply would be adequate. If it is in fact
"the cheapest box in Fry's" I'd wager it's only _actually_ able to deliver
250 Watts or less of sustained power. Some PSU manufacturers (especially the
cheapies) will rate their units based on peak output, never mind how clean
or sustained that output will be.

If you want to say goodbye to power issues forever, get a PC Power and
Cooling unit. I've used them in several machines over the years, and they've
all been flawless. I see that they have a Silencer 470 available for $99.
That would likely treat you well.
http://www.pcpower.com/products/viewproduct.php?show=S47ATX

Other brands I've good luck with include Zalman, Thermaltake, Antec,
Enermax, and Enlight.

I've always considered PSU's to be the "redheaded step child" of computer
building. Nobody pays them any attention, until they start causing trouble.
A good PSU is worth investing in, and will usually be a relatively small
portion of the total cost of the machine.
-- 
-Regards-

-Quentin Hartman-

if I run just 'set -x; parted pfSense-1.0.1-Embedded.img unit B print':

+ parted pfSense-1.0.1-Embedded.img unit B print
WARNING: You are not superuser.  Watch out for permissions.
Error: Invalid partition table - recursive partition on                   
/home/ehouse/wrap/pfSense-1.0.1-Embedded.img.
Ignore/Cancel? i                                                          

Disk /home/ehouse/wrap/pfSense-1.0.1-Embedded.img: 122441727B

Partition Table: msdos

"slice" (= linux partition) -- plus the MBR of course.  When dd'd to
/dev/hda it results in something that to Linux fdisk has a single partition,
hda4.  (IIRC)

On Tue, 1 May 2007 06:45:48 -0700
"Quentin Hartman" <qhartman at gmail.com> dijo:

> I'd wager a _good_ 380 Watt power supply would be adequate. If it is in fact
> "the cheapest box in Fry's" I'd wager it's only _actually_ able to deliver
> 250 Watts or less of sustained power. Some PSU manufacturers (especially the
> cheapies) will rate their units based on peak output, never mind how clean
> or sustained that output will be.

You may be right about the output of the "380 watt" power supply in the
"cheapest box in Fry's." It is a Raidmax box and the PS is also
Raidmax. It says it has one 15 amp 12V rail, which isn't a lot. 

I declined the advice re PC Power and Cooling. I had a bad experience
with them several years ago on a "super-quiet" PS that was warranted
for two years. It failed at 1 year, 11 1/2 months. When I called they
said the warranty began when they took it into inventory and, checking
my unit, that was a month earlier than when I bought it. "Read the fine
print" is all they would say. Of course, I no longer could find the
agreement. But the experience left a bad taste in my mouth and I will
never do business with them again.

Instead I went to Fry's and got an Antec "Earth 80" 500 watt PS that
has two 18 amp 12 volt rails. It is installed and seemed to be working
fine, but I couldn't do any formatting to put it through its paces
because of another problem. The last power failure evidently mucked
up /dev/md1, which has the OS on it. It gets to the point where Grub is
supposed to say things like "stage 1.5," and then it just hangs with
the word "Grub" at the bottom of the screen. 

I tried the GRML rescue CD that I downloaded the other day on the
recommendation of Michael M. It has mdadm and finds the md devices on
booting. I started with e2fsck on /dev/md1 and it announced that it had
been 47,719 days since it was last checked and that its last write time
was in the future (fix, y/n?). I told it to go ahead and it proceeded
to check the whole thing. It finished without any other errors. I did
the same thing for /dev/md2 and got the same results.

Then I tried /dev/md3. This is the one where I know the array is broken
-- one of its two drives doesn't show up in cat /proc/mdstat. E2fsck gave
me more serious error messages and I told it to go ahead and fix
things. Eventually it got to the point where it needed to restore the
file system on /dev/sdb4. I told it to go ahead and it proceeded to
start formatting sdb4. About one minute into the process and I was
staring at a black screen again. No power.

So I got up, made sure that each of the 320 GB Sata II drives was on a
different rail, and restarted. I got to the formatting part and, once
again, after about a minute the machine shut down.

The only items in this computer are two 320 GB Sata II drives, on AMD-2
4600 64-bit CPU and two DVD drives. No video card. No network card. I
use the video and network on the motherboard. There is nothing else in
the computer. 

Surely two 18 amp 12 volt rails should be adequate. Obviously something
else is going on. It always and only happens when I try to format the
250 GB partitions. Software issue? Something shutting down the computer
if it thinks someone is formatting a drive? Bug in fsck? Bad hard drive
(brand new, Western Digital Caviar)? Feed caviar to the drives?

> Surely two 18 amp 12 volt rails should be adequate. Obviously something
> else is going on. It always and only happens when I try to format the

This sounds a *little* like an overheating thing, but that's really a
long-shot.  I don't know of many things that will intentionally make a
computer go black like that.  Generally this would be almost certainly
be accompanied by some form of beeping, hopefully from a small
on-board speaker (not the pc speaker, or not *just* the pc speaker),
but if for some reason the speakers are borked, this could be the
reason...

Anyway, just throwing that out as something to check.  Pop into your
bios and see what the thermal alarms are set to, and maybe tweak them
down a *lot* and see if the same thing happens under a controlled
test.

--Rogan

On Tue, 1 May 2007 17:58:53 -0700
"Rogan Creswick" <creswick at gmail.com> dijo:

> This sounds a *little* like an overheating thing, but that's really a
> long-shot.  I don't know of many things that will intentionally make a
> computer go black like that.  Generally this would be almost certainly
> be accompanied by some form of beeping, hopefully from a small

> bios and see what the thermal alarms are set to, and maybe tweak them
> down a *lot* and see if the same thing happens under a controlled

Temperature is a good idea. However, checking the BIOS, I'm pretty sure
it is not the problem here. The BIOS page for PC Health says:

Shutdown Temperature	80C
Warning Temperature	75C

And then it displays the current stats, changing them while I watched
(I put the range next to the item)

CPU T Control			39-43C
System Temperature	40C
CPU fan Speed		1003 - 1054 RPM
System Fan Speed		0 RPM 
CPU Vcore			1.28V
VDIMM				1.87V

The system fan speed is 0 because it is mounted on the side of the case
and the side of the case has been off for days. In other words, small
animals could move in and nest.

However, the one thing of interest that is not listed is the temp of
the hard drives. I don't think there are any sensors on them. They are
warm to the touch, but not unpleasantly so. 

More to the point, the problem happens always and only about a minute
after starting to format the 250 GB partitions, and it occurs exactly
the same way whether the system has been running all day or has been
shut off and is dead cold.

I think we have to rule out heat.

I'm also leaning against a bug issue. It is certainly possible that
something in that messed up /dev/md3 could be so broken that it sends
e2fsck into a tizzy. But if there was a bug in e2fsk it should cause a
kernel panic and hang the computer, or puke up a screenful of error
messages and abort. I've never heard of a software bug that could
summarily power down the computer.

If it were the CPU I'd be having problems all over the place.

I think the only hardware left to consider are the hard disks. Is there
any software that will scan them to see if there are any physical
defects?

I'm not using Gnome or KDE, BTW, so I don't get any cute printer
config GUIs.  All the online how-tos seem to assume that you're using
KDE/Gnome *or* that your printer has an ethernet port itself.

Message-ID: <8975a95f0705012014t7ad0a4a2l5372a75291a1e305@mail.gmail.com>

On 5/1/07, John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
>
>
> If it were the CPU I'd be having problems all over the place.
>
> I think the only hardware left to consider are the hard disks. Is there
> any software that will scan them to see if there are any physical
> defects?
>

Try doing some other I/O intensive thing, like "cat /dev/zero > zeroes.dat"
or something similar to workout the HDD. Perhaps it is a heat issue, but
it's not in the CPU, but rather the drive controller on the Southbridge...

Download the Ultimate Boot CD and run MHDD on the drives (hard disk tools,
4th or 5th page, item F5. Once in MHDD, select your drive and hit F4 to
bring up the scan option window and then hit F4 again to start it) as that
will certainly work them out in a way completely isolated from your
potentially questionsable system image.

-- 
-Regards-

From robert.citek at gmail.com  Tue May  1 22:10:37 2007
From: robert.citek at gmail.com (Robert Citek)
Date: Wed, 02 May 2007 00:10:37 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] Modifying a FreeBSD disk image
In-Reply-To: <20070501140635.GX2770@amethyst.spiritone.com>
References: <20070501052213.B797142F8@ulke.nakedape.cc>
	<20070501140635.GX2770@amethyst.spiritone.com>
Message-ID: <46381D4D.8010402@gmail.com>

eehouse.org wrote:
> I believe the image has a number of FreeBSD partions within a single
> "slice" (= linux partition) -- plus the MBR of course.  When dd'd to
> /dev/hda it results in something that to Linux fdisk has a single partition,
> hda4.  (IIRC)

Odd.  I don't have a BSD disk image handy, but I do have one of an OS X
drive.  Running an older version of parted on it returns this output:

# parted /tmp/sda.img print
Disk geometry for /tmp/sda.img: 0.000-57231.562 megabytes
Disk label type: mac
Minor    Start       End     Filesystem  Name                  Flags
1          0.000      0.031              Apple
2          0.031      0.058              Macintosh
3          0.059      0.085              Macintosh
4          0.086      0.113              Macintosh
5          0.113      0.140              Macintosh
6          0.141      0.390              Macintosh
7          0.391      0.640              Macintosh
8          0.641      0.890              Patch Partition
9          0.891  57231.558  hfs         Untitled


With newer versions of parted, you can specify the unit size in bytes.
By knowing the start and end byte-count you can use dd to extract the
partition out of the disk image file, or mount it via the loop-back
device with an offset value.

Since parted didn't work, the next thing I'd try is to dd the image to a
real drive and then to dd just the partition you need to a file.

Regards,
- Robert

> wamorita at hevanet.com

> Cell: (503) 260-3876

As crazy as it might sound, you may want to make sure your White Box
is loading the appropriate kernel module(s) to enable disk access
(namely, the ext3 module, plus any lower-level disk access drivers
like libata).  I'll bet that knoppix is loading the necessary drivers,
and an lsmod will reveal all.

Once booted under knoppix, you could chroot to your root filesystem
and build a new, custom kernel that has all the necessary drivers
compiled into the kernel image, avoiding the module issue altogether.
It's nice to avoid having to troubleshoot initrd images.

Carlos Konstanski

First I downloaded the UCBD and used it to run the Western Digital
Lifesaver Diagnostic tool on each of the hard disks. It ran for 75
minutes each time with the hard drive light on solid the whole time. No
errors on either disk. Then I ran memtest86 for an hour, and no
problems. 

I discovered something while booting the UCBD -- at the start it
presents a simple little word "boot" on the screen and if you don't hit
Enter fast enough it will continue and boot from the hard disk instead
of the CD. One time I was not fast enough and it booted from the hard
disk. The interesting thing is that if I just boot without the CD I get
to the point where it says "GRUB" and then hangs. But if the UCBD
starts first and then it goes to the hard disk, Feisty actually starts
to boot. It crashes to a command line, but the kernel loads.

I figured that meant that maybe there was something in menu.lst that I
could fix. However, I have a dozen or more live CDs of various flavors
and only two will show the md devices when I run cat /proc/dev. One is
GRML Rescue CD and the other is Aaron's rescue CD. Aaron's won't
mount /dev/md1, but the GRML Rescue CD will. However, it does something
weird that I have not figured out. I mounted /dev/md1 at /mnt/md1. When
I do "nano /mnt/md1/boot/grub/menu.lst" I get a menu.lst file, but it
is GRML's menu.lst -- it's definitely not mine. Yet navigating around
in /mnt/md1/ all the rest is mine, that is, it finds /home/jjj and all
the files in it are mine. Weird.

So I started downloading a bunch of other rescue CDs. So far none of
them can see /dev/md*. While doing the downloading I tried
"cat /dev/zero > zeroes.dat" and it powered off the computer after a
couple of minutes. I read what little there is in man cat, but couldn't
figure out what exactly this command does. What does it mean that it
caused a shutdown?

cat just reads the contents of a file and outputs it to the terminal. tac
does the same thing but starts from the bottom of a file whereas cat starts
from the top of the file. It shouldn't have caused a shutdown, sounds like a
dodgy power supply to me.

though.

It looks like you're attempting to write to the boot media (ie CD), you need
to change directories to a mount point on the hard drive you want to test
then run the command or insert the mount point of your hard drive into the
output file name like so:

cat /dev/zero > /mnt/feisty/home/jjj/zeroes.dat or similar

On 5/2/07, John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote
> weird that I have not figured out. I mounted /dev/md1 at /mnt/md1. When
> I do "nano /mnt/md1/boot/grub/menu.lst" I get a menu.lst file, but ital

This sounds like /mnt/md1/boot/grub/menu.lst is a soft link to another file.
Find out which file it is pointing to  ( ls -altr /mnt/md1/boot/grub
will tell you)
Then add /mnt/md1 to the beginning of  the file it is pointing to to
find the real menu.lst.

Bill

                        The Portland Linux/Unix Group
                                  will meet

                            Smith Memorial Center

      *******************************************************************

                                 PRESENTATION

                     Developer and Customer Focused Tests
                                     for
                              a LAMP Environment

                                      by

                               Ward Cunningham
                                <ward at c2.com>
                 Director of Committer Community Development
                            The Eclipse Foundation

      Agile methods such as Extreme Programming (XP) rely on a
      readily repeated suite of tests to give developers the courage
      they need to continuously improve their code.

      In this talk XP pioneer Ward Cunningham will dissect the agile
      testing strategy and framework that the Portland Eclipse
      Foundation team created while developing the recently deployed
      MyFoundation Portal, a LAMP application.

      The testing framework is notable for two reasons. One, it has
      been deployed into production with the application and serves
      as "open and transparent" documentation. Two, it integrates
      with the application in such a way to make it both simple and
      powerful at the small expense of some test coverage.

      Part 3 of Ward's blog series on the portal includes more
      explanation, screen shots, and a link to the live test site.
      Find the blog series here:
      http://dash.eclipse.org/~ward/portal-blog/

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu May  3 12:46:20 2007
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Thu, 03 May 2007 12:46:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] tar help
In-Reply-To: <727fc2ee0705031226o6e8eb121h9ef33a9b911f12fb@mail.gmail.com>
References: <727fc2ee0705031226o6e8eb121h9ef33a9b911f12fb@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <463A3C0C.5080304@seitzassoc.com>

User Iam wrote:
> I can never remember
> 
> tar  -xvf   some.tar   <how do I tell it where to go>
> 
> I want it to be in the root directory

Assuming the tar file uses relative paths, the following should do 
what you want.

cd /
tar -xvf path_to_tar_file/some.tar

Just to be safe, I typically untar into a scratch directory under tmp, 
then move the files/directories into the proper place.

Checking the man page, it looks like gnu tar normally strips any 
leading slash from filenames in the tar file, so that should not be an 
issue.  I don't believe this is necessarily the case with all tar 
implementations.

galen

From qhartman at gmail.com  Thu May  3 12:56:57 2007
From: qhartman at gmail.com (Quentin Hartman)
Date: Thu, 3 May 2007 12:56:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Eye candy Web pages
In-Reply-To: <463A3611.1090002@alcpress.com>

On 5/3/07, Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> wrote:
>
> I'm updating some web sites so they don't look like
> they were designed by an oaf with no eye for style (me).
> For the BizNix site, for example, I'd like something that
> scrolls words and phrases in some sexy way. If you look
> at the main page (http://biznix.org/) now, I have a
> Javascript text scroller that minimally does the job.
> It doesn't look great.


There are about a million different ways to skin this cat. I'd bet if you
spent some time browsing one of the many javascript repository sites out
there, you'd find a script that does what you want elegantly.
Dynamicdrive.com has a number of example scripts that might get you started.
Depending on what exactly you're looking for, it might just need some CSS
love to look good.

I see that the Javascript scroller places quite a demand
> on the CPU at the browser side (of course). I'm wondering
> whether Flash would be a better choice. I have no
> experience creating Flash content. What does it take to
> create Flash content on Linux or the iMac?


As the amount of "flash" you want to have increases, so does the
appropriateness of Flash. Personally, I consider Flash a last resort. As far
as authoring, there is not a whole lot on Linux, though there is some.
Unfortunately, the specific names of the projects escape me at the moment. I
seem to recall them being less than fully baked, however. On the iMac, you
have lots of options, Adobe's entire line of tools should be available.

Or should I consider some other way of producing this
> content?


I think you should stick with JS until you are sure what you want can't be
accomplished with it. It's generally more portable and accessible than
Flash. I find it useful to do non-functional mockups of sites to get the
design done before I try to implement it for real. Use whatever tool you're
most comfortable with, be it photoshop, inkscape, openoffice, or NVU. Get
the design where you want it, then try to tackle the implementation
obstacles. If you find something you can't get past, revisit the design
mockup and change it accordingly.

-- 
-Regards-

-Quentin Hartman-

From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)

Ed Sawicki wrote:
> I see that the Javascript scroller places quite a demand
> on the CPU at the browser side (of course). I'm wondering
> whether Flash would be a better choice. I have no
> experience creating Flash content. What does it take to
> create Flash content on Linux or the iMac?

The javascript doesn't place much demand on my system, it's hard to tell 
how much as it gets lost in the noise of everything else that runs.  I'm 
using ff2 on what's probably a middle of the road box.

If you want to go the flash route, as far as I know there's no fancy 
flash authoring tools for linux, the Mac is well supported by Adobe but 
the tools aren't free (~$700 list for flash cs3).  You can use something 
like Ming (http://ming.sourceforge.net/) or you can probably find a 
canned free/free as in beer/shareware flash movie that'll do what you 
need too.

--Brent

> Abit NF-M2S with onboard Gigabit and nVidia GeForce 6100 and 405 chipset
> Two 320 GB SATA II drives
> Two DVD+-RW Dual layer
> AMD-2 4600 64-bit
> Two 1-GB Corsair RAM
> Raidmax case, replaced PS with Antec 500 w
>
> Any time I have extensive disk activity I get a sudden power off, like
> pulling the power plug out of the back. I have run the Western Digital
> Lifesaver Diagnostic Utility on the Ultimate Boot CD and it ran all the
> way through (70+ minutes) with the hard drive light on constantly the
> whole time. No errors. But formatting a partition will power off the
> computer after a few minutes. So will adding a device with mdadm.
>
> I have replaced the the power supply and I have swapped the motherboard
> for a new one, but the problem persists.
>
> In the BIOS there is an option to shutdown on certain errors. I set it
> to "no errors." I think that applies to booting only, but I'm grasping
> at straws here.
>
> Does anyone know if there is a list somewhere of hardware faults that
> can cause a sudden power off? If this was your box, what would you
> suspect next?

Over current on any output line of the power supply.  Possibly the CPU now doing
too much and sucking the power supply off line?

To prove it would be the CPU and not the HDs find something that is
CPU intensive
and run it.  If you can get close  to 100% on both CPUs then I would think that
you have a HD error causing the problem.  HD formatting doesn't work a
HD very hard.

Being that I'm a Computer Based Training developer part time, I'm a
bit biased towards Flash because you can use it to do just about
anything you can imagine.

In terms of some of the creativity you can offer, sites such as
www.cavemanscrib.com and www.27bobs.com comes to mine.  But there are
a bunch of examples that would just blow your mind.

Unfortunately, the Flash IDE is built for Windoze and MAC.  However,
you might want to check out www.osflash.org (Open Source Flash).  It
is a site deditacted to providing free examples and 3rd party open
source (free) products.  You can get around the IDE using things such
as HAXE and SwfMill.

Ben

I can't speak for your customers, but I have never seen an 
animation/flash component that didn't hit me somewhere on the scale 
between annoyed and almost literally sick.  I occasionally wonder how 
many seizures are caused by blinking web sites.

Maybe blinking red on green is the answer, but I would imagine a 
tasteful design with professional photographs (you know, the whole 
"smart-looking, happy customer" thing) and nice logos would be most 
effective.  The hypothesis being that 98% of the animations on the web 
are basically cheap hacks at the "dynamicity" which a talented 
artist/designer can deliver in a still.

Of course, movement doesn't have to be tacky and distracting.  It's all 
about subtlety.

On Thu, 3 May 2007 14:41:00 -0700
"Larry Brigman" <larry.brigman at gmail.com> dijo:

> > Does anyone know if there is a list somewhere of hardware faults that
> > can cause a sudden power off? If this was your box, what would you
> > suspect next?
> 
> Over current on any output line of the power supply.  Possibly the CPU now doing
> too much and sucking the power supply off line?
> 
> To prove it would be the CPU and not the HDs find something that is
> CPU intensive
> and run it.  If you can get close  to 100% on both CPUs then I would think that
> you have a HD error causing the problem.  HD formatting doesn't work a
> HD very hard.

First, to Alan, yes I have run memtest86+, although only for an hour.
However, there are two memory slots and each has a 1 GB Corsair stick
in it. I removed the stick that was in slot 1 and moved the stick from
slot 2 into it. There was no change in the problem. Assuming that slot
1 is the first one to be used, and none of the things I have been doing
have used very much RAM, I am guessing that this eliminates RAM as an
issue.

For my most recent attempt I reset the BIOS using the jumper on the
motherboard, then entered the BIOS and set it to "Optimized defaults."
This is what Abit recommends for new installations or any time there
are problems. When I rebooted I was surprised to see Feisty start to
load even though there was a GRML Rescue CD in the drive. Then I
realized that "Optimized defaults" must have set the initial boot drive
to the hard disk. Lame, but oh well. 

The interesting thing is that Feisty actually booted all the way up. I
haven't seen Feisty running on this box for about four days now. I just
stared at it for a while and then left it running while I worked at the
laptop. I never touched the mouse or keyboard. After about 15 minutes
the screen went black and computer shut down. All by itself. 

So then I restarted it, went into the BIOS, and changed the boot order
so it would boot from the CD. I had the GRML Rescue CD in the drive, so
when I exited the BIOS that is what came up. But it won't even finish
booting without getting shut down. I tried it several times, but I
can't get the GRML Rescue CD to finish booting.  I think things are
getting worse.

I guess next I need to check the CPU. The Ultimate Boot CD has CPU
tests, but only for Intel CPUs. This is AM-2 64-bit. I'll google and
see if I can turn something up.

From johnxj at comcast.net  Thu May  3 21:33:12 2007
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Thu, 3 May 2007 21:33:12 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] hardware errors
In-Reply-To: <B78F0107028C4257BDC683AD7EA2162E@Valenth>
References: <20070503220339.26C6A440C@ulke.nakedape.cc>
	<B78F0107028C4257BDC683AD7EA2162E@Valenth>
Message-ID: <20070503213312.9e4b7549.johnxj@comcast.net>

On Thu, 03 May 2007 18:49:34 -0700
"Christine Navarro" <christine.navarro at verizon.net> dijo:

> Perhaps you've already removed this possibility by setting your BIOS to no 
> errors, but I had a computer a while back that would shut down.  There was a 
> temperature setting in the BIOS that would shut down the machine when the 
> CPU reached a certain temp...

Not to pick on Christine, but I must make something clear. It cannot be
heat. It happens when the machine is stone cold. Plus the BIOS settings
for temperature warning and shutdown are dsabled. 

It happened *once* when formatting a large partition. However it
happens repeatedly and reliably when creating a large RAID 1 partition.
I got it to the point where Feisty will load and run normally. No
sudden shutdowns -- over an hour of using it for all kinds of things.
In order to accomplish this I deleted the /dev/md3 RAID 1 array that I
had attempted to create previously. 

Once I was sure Feisty was finally stable I used Gparted to create two
new unformatted partitions, a matching one on each of the two hard
drives, sda and sdb. Each partition is 238 MB, sda4 and sdb4. Then,
still using Gparted, I set the flags on each partition to RAID. Then I
shut down Gparted because that is as far as Gparted can go in creating
a RAID. For the rest you need mdadm. So here is the code for what I did
next with mdadm:

jjj at Devil6:~$ sudo mdadm --create /dev/md3 --level=1
	--raid-devices=2 /dev/sd[ab]4 jjj at Devil6:~$ password
jjj at Devil6:~$ <messages about finding sda4 and sdb4>
jjj at Devil6:~$ Create array? (Y/N) y
jjj at Devil6:~$ Created array
jjj at Devil6:~$ 

Now, there is a little documentation problem with the above code. Mdadm
doesn't say so, but after it says "Created array" it is not finished.
It will now proceed to do mkfs on /dev/md3, and that will take about
1.75 hours. The hard drive light will stay on constantly until it is
finished. 

Four or five minutes later I get a shutdown.

If I reboot any version of any distro, the mnute it finishes booting,
the mkfs command automatically starts up again. Of course, because of
the shutdown the previous efforts are wiped out and it must start
formatting /dev/md3 over again from the start. The hard disk light is
on constantly.

Four or five minutes later I get a shutdown.

If i reboot i can get Feisty to run perfectly normally by opening a
terminal and typing "sudo mdadm -S /dev/md3." That stops it from
continuing to format and sync /dev/md3. The hard disk light goes out.
Feisty then continues to run perfectly normally for as long as I want
to keep it running.

So something is now becoming clear to me. I think I don't have a real
problem with any of the hardware. Where I have a problem is using Linux
software RAID on these drives. A wild guess is that it has to do with
the fact that it is essentially formatting both disks at the same time
and making sure the blocks are synced. The drives are not liking this. 

Consider also that at one time before I discovered that you cannot set
a RAID flag on a partition once it has been formatted, I created the
238 GB partition and had Gparted format it (a single drive at a time).
The formatting proceeded and ended normally.

I would suggest that it's a bug in mdadm, but "incompatibility" might
be more accurate. Perhaps there's something about these drives that
mdadm cannot handle. Yet, I did create a 2 GB RAID 1 swap, a 20 and a
40 GB regular RAID 1 partition, and they proceeded normally. But when I
created those I used the GUI in Etch and Feisty Alternate,
respectively. I'm assuming the GUI is a front end for mdadm, so perhaps
the reason those proceeded was because they were smaller. I don't know.
I just know that I have finally isolated exactly when it is happening.
I think for my next exercise I need to google on bugs for mdadm and
perhaps communicate with its developers.

I hope the meeting went well tonight. I have an early morning class and
needed to spend some time on a paper so I could not go. Thanks to all
who offered suggestions. And if anyone has any further thoughts about
mdadm, please let me know.

From creswick at gmail.com  Thu May  3 22:04:14 2007
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Thu, 3 May 2007 22:04:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] tar help
In-Reply-To: <9AA63704-1B0C-4A59-BA84-D3F0DDCE61F9@scottshill.com>
References: <9AA63704-1B0C-4A59-BA84-D3F0DDCE61F9@scottshill.com>
Message-ID: <c834ec80705032204u5504db6dl50eeaa55fe9ee850@mail.gmail.com>

On 5/3/07, Kenneth B. Hill <ken at scottshill.com> wrote:
> I hope that I am replying to the list correctly; I get them in a
> bundle once or twice a day.

Generally, it's preferred to reply in-line, so we can tell what you're
replying to.  If you become active in the group you may consider
switching from digest mode to getting each message separately.  Any
email client worth it's salt (and many, many clients that *aren't*)
will be able to filter email from the list in a way that makes the
bulk of email manageable.  It helps the rest of us with threading, at
the very least. (since digest messages usually break email threading)

> What is the difference between tar and
> zip (or gzip or gz).

gzip compresses single files -- as far as I know, gzip will not create
a compressed archive of a number of files on it's own.  "zip" is
another tool entirely (although it accomplishes a *similar* function.
More on zip later.)

tar does the other half of what most people need -- it combines files
into one, but does not compress them.  (There is a *lot* more to tar
than that, but I'm not the person to go into it.)

tar and gzip follow the unix philosophy pretty closely:  Do one task,
and do that task very well.  In order to compress a whole host of
files, you need to tar them, and then gzip the result.  Now days, tar
is capable of calling gzip (or bzip2) directly, so you don't need
multiple commands, but in the past, you needed to pipe tar to gzip, or
run tar, and then manually gzip the result.  This is at least part of
the reason you see so many files ending in .tar.gz -- they are tar's
(files created by tar) that have been gziped (hence the .gz).
Slackware packages use the more terse .tgz, which may have other
connotations, like being compatible with the slackware "install"
utilities, but under the hood these files are also tar.gz's.

You could think of tar as a bag to hold things, and gzip as
compression straps that make it smaller.  Without the bag, the
contents would just go squirting all over the place.

zip does the task of both tar and gzip, but it's not as unix-y.  IIRC,
it was originally a dos tool, but I'm not 100% sure of that.

At this point, most windows machines will open a .tar.gz (recent
versions of winzip are perfectly happy opening them).

--Rogan

Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> Anyone hooked up to hughes.net from their linux box or a SOHO network?
> If so do I need to get anything _extra_ to make it work?

I can't offer any personal experience, but I'm interested in how it
works out for your friend.

I did a Google search on 'RV "high speed Internet"' awhile back.
Eventually I found this page:

http://www.copperhead.cc/fap.htm

It explains the hughes.net Fair Access Policy. It's hughes.net's way of
preventing anyone from doing lots of downloads a lot of the time. Once
you get to your quota your effective download speed drops to that of a
56k baud modem and stays there for the "recovery period", which may be
8-12 hours (see the above web site for details). It would become a
problem if one is trying to download an install DVD, for example.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens

technique that tries to convert the highly
interactive HTTP/TCP into a more efficient
protocol for long-delay satellite channels. I don't
know if it's handled in their "modem" or if there's
a client-side (browser-side) component.

From ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com  Sat May  5 19:11:35 2007
From: ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Sat, 5 May 2007 20:11:35 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba Problem
In-Reply-To: <e2aeccd60705051848v1167158fvcbf8d184ca51131c@mail.gmail.com>
References: <463D2D47.4020604@comcast.net>
	<e2aeccd60705051848v1167158fvcbf8d184ca51131c@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0705052002460.7006@sphinktoo.pippiandcarlos.com>

If you want username and password protection, you simply need to add
users to the smbpasswd file with:

     smbpasswd -a <username>

and add "encrypt_passwords = yes" to the global section of smb.conf.

Sometimes it's handy to fire up swat, but make a backup of your
smb.conf file first.  It's a handy way to browse all the possible
samba config settings.  Once you get a good smb.conf, though, guard it
like you would your kernel .config file.

Carlos Konstanski

Date: Sat, 17 Mar 2007 11:27:30 -0700
From: Raven Zachary <raven.zachary at the451group.com>
Subject: Save the date! BarCamp Portland Tech Unconference, May 11-12

I am pleased to announce that BarCamp is coming to Portland on May 11-12! We will also be
kicking off the regular DemoCamp event series during BarCamp to highlight tech startup activity
in the Portland area.

Tech + Geek + Culture. The event for the Portland tech community, produced BY the Portland tech
community.

What is BarCamp? It is an ad-hoc gathering born from the desire for people to share and learn in
an open environment. It is an intense event with discussions, demos, and interaction from
participants.

BarCamp is a FREE event and the content is determined by the attendees. The event will be hosted
at CubeSpace, which has a number of conference rooms for breakout sessions, a large main meeting
area, wireless access, easy access to public transportation, bike storage, and ample parking.
Thanks to Eva and David at CubeSpace for signing up as space sponsors for the event (and to Ray
at AboutUs for sponsoring the additional space costs).

We need your help to make BarCamp Portland a fantastic event for the tech community in Portland.
Here's what you can do...

1) Forward this email on to people in the Portland area that may have an interest in attending.
As we have done little marketing of the event (so far), assume that your local tech social
network doesn't know about it yet.

2) If you have not already added yourself to the BarCamp Portland wiki page as an attendee,
please do so. This will help us get a more accurate attendance count and plan accordingly (you
want food, right?):

http://barcamp.org/BarCampPortland

3) Add a session idea for the event. This could be a talk, a demo, a roundtable discussions -
whatever! Please add it to the Proposed Sessions section on the wiki page:

http://barcamp.org/BarCampPortland

4) Attend the BarCamp Portland Meetup this Thursday (03/22) evening 5:30-8pm at Jive Software
downtown. Free beer on tap (thanks, Jive!), the opportunity to network with the tech community
in Portland, and help plan for BarCamp Portland. More details:

http://barcamp.org/BarCampPortlandMeetups

5) Help identify sponsors. CubeSpace and AboutUs are already onboard as sponsors for the space
and related costs (and Jive Software has been our ongoing meetup and planning sponsor). We are
looking for sponsors to cover food, drinks, and t-shirts.

I hope to see you this Thursday evening at Jive Software for our monthly tech meetup and BarCamp
Portland planning meeting!


Raven Zachary
Research Director, Open Source
The 451 Group

> I can't offer any personal experience, but I'm interested in how it
> works out for your friend.
> 
> I did a Google search on 'RV "high speed Internet"' awhile back.
> Eventually I found this page:
> 
> http://www.copperhead.cc/fap.htm
> 
> It explains the hughes.net Fair Access Policy. It's hughes.net's way of
> preventing anyone from doing lots of downloads a lot of the time. Once
> you get to your quota your effective download speed drops to that of a
> 56k baud modem and stays there for the "recovery period", which may be
> 8-12 hours (see the above web site for details). It would become a
> problem if one is trying to download an install DVD, for example.
> 

I think this is true with all Sat ISP's.  They limit in overall 
transfer.  Not pretty after you hit that limit.  But even while 
operating normally, my friends church (in clackamas) has outage problems 
weekly, and the speed is very inconsistent.  Support literally tells him 
it will be a week before someone can come out and help.  His modem, and 
most other Sat modems are standard DOCSIS modems, the same as any cable 
modem.  So platform shouldn't matter.  I have an OpenBSD firewall 
getting the first IP at his location.

From m0gely at telestream.com  Sun May  6 11:26:41 2007
From: m0gely at telestream.com (m0gely)
Date: Sun, 06 May 2007 11:26:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Eye candy Web pages
In-Reply-To: <463A57D1.2030602@alcpress.com>
References: <463A3611.1090002@alcpress.com>	<c834ec80705031312w2e4bf069m33f5e6dc17599c55@mail.gmail.com>
	<463A57D1.2030602@alcpress.com>
Message-ID: <463E1DE1.7000807@telestream.com>

Ed Sawicki wrote:

> I'm a technical geek happy to look at static and understated
> content. I prefer function over form. But lately I've been
> paying more attention to what other people, such as my
> customers, think. Animation and sexy graphics make a big
> difference to them. A company with inferior products can
> easily gain the edge with a good looking Web site.

This assumes you truly understand where function and form meet, and can 
stay away from where they do battle.  What your customers think is often 
difficult to articulate in your own mind.  As my brother who does 
graphics design knows well.  Often times what he thinks stinks, his 
customers love and vice-versa.

Tickers and scrollers are not sexy, period.  Animations 99% of the time 
are a really bad idea.  But this is somewhat dependent on the 
implementation and the target audience.  Most people just want to get 
where they need to go quickly.  Try to make your site navigation 
intuitive and make as much as you can available in two clicks or less.

I was just perusing the leatherman.com site this morning, and it does 
really well with the two click rule and having the animations integrated 
in an appropriate manner.

If you really want a good looking website, hire someone to do it for you 
who does this for a living.  You can have Joomla! templates custom made 
for around $1200 to $1500, or pick one already made that's close to what 
you like for less than $100.  They also have several free templates. 
Just expect those to be used on several other sites around then web too.

I have seen several articles linked on digg.com that point to good web 
design etiquette.  Many of them all say the same thing.  I would read up 
on it if you want to do this yourself.

Of course, the above is opinion and I don't claim to be an authority on 
web design.  You'll find the same suggestions in many places online though.

-- 
- m0gely


From znmeb at cesmail.net  Sun May  6 13:40:57 2007
From: znmeb at cesmail.net (M. Edward (Ed) Borasky)
Date: Sun, 06 May 2007 13:40:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] The bullet has been bitten
Message-ID: <463E3D59.3080509@cesmail.net>

I finally got around to taking the dual-core 64-bit plunge, specifically 
with an AMD Athlon 64 X2 4200+. So far:

1. Ubuntu Feisty Fawn freezes in the install -- buh bye Ubuntu!

2. Debian Etch installs flawlessly but has frozen twice. I'm not sure 
what that is -- looks like kernel and not hardware but I can't be sure.

3. CentOS 5 installs flawlessly even with Xen. I haven't had it up long 
enough to know whether it will freeze or not, and it needs some X 
tweaking, but other than that I think it's OK.

4. Fedora? Why bother?

I took a couple of shots at Gentoo and had all kinds of kernel issues 
with their 2006.1 media, and 2007.0 isn't released yet. So ... next step 
is to pick the more stable of CentOS or Etch and bootstrap Gentoo in 
that way. So I'll have a clean kernel, etc., on the Gentoo side. But 
meanwhile it looks like CentOS is the horse to beat.

power offs but I do get freezes. Feisty Fawn was the worst -- it 
couldn't even pull off an install. I've gotten Etch and CentOS 5 
installs to complete reliably, and they both use some flavor of 2.4.18 
stabilized kernel. I had a couple of freezes in Etch during disk 
activity, but I haven't hit CentOS 5 hard enough yet to know if it does 
the same thing.

I got one "OOPS" traceback out of Etch. If I can get something 
reproducible I'll post it to the Debian mailing lists. And once I get 
Gentoo installed I'll do most of my debugging there, because that's what 
I really want to run on this box. :) But I'd look at kernels before 
hardware at this point.


From johnxj at comcast.net  Sun May  6 15:01:09 2007

On Sun, 06 May 2007 13:55:44 -0700
"M. Edward (Ed) Borasky" <znmeb at cesmail.net> dijo:

> What's your kernel? I'm just now taking the Athlon 64 X2 plunge, at a

> I really want to run on this box. :) But I'd look at kernels before 
> hardware at this point.

This new box is ultimately to be used as a storage area for backups and
as an alternative way to get on the net when I screw up my laptop,
which will be my main computer indefinitely. Therefore, I have to
luxury of playing hard with it, like installing all kinds of distros,
wiping out, starting over, etc. 

I tried a lot of distros, all 64-bit:

Fedora 7 test2, updated to test3+ before giving up. It ran flawlessly,
but RPM and I will never be friends. Package management is a pain for
someone brought up on Ubuntu like me. I missed me my Synaptic! Fedora
was one of only two that automatically detected the nVidia GeForce
6100, and even the ViewSonic Graphics Series G90f monitor. However, it
failed hopelessly with the Realtek gigabit on the motherboard. Most
others did as well, but they ignored it. Fedora would go into a kernel
panic on booting unless I disabled the Realtek in the BOS.

Gentoo 2006.1 was the only other one that found and autoconfigured the
video and monitor. However, it ignored the gigabit. I couldn't get it
to do a RAID 1 partition. It recognized a RAID 1 partition created by
another distro and installed itself on it, but its installed could not
create a new RAID partition. 

Mandriva-free 2007 did sort of OK, but couldn't handle the video or the
gigabit. I wasn't impressed, and considering that it is
semi-commercial, to hell iwth it.

OpenSuse 10.2, ditto Mandriva-free 2007

Simply Mepis 6.5 rc2, couldn't recognize the video or the gigabit, and
was way too stripped down for my taste. 

CentOS 5, ditto what I said about Simply Mepis.

Debian Etch worked very well. It and Ubuntu were the only ones that
could handle the Realtek 8169SC gigabit. However, neither could
recognize or configure the video. I abandoned Etch in favor of Feisty
because Feisty has more candy and better support (the forums rock).

Ubuntu Feisty, using the Alternate install CD worked great out of the
box. It autoconfigured the gigabit, but not the video. However, it is
easy to install the nVidia driver with Ubuntu, ditto for audio and
video codecs and stuff. With a couple clicks I installed 32-bit
RealPlayer, 32-bit Adobe Reader 7.0.8, 32-bit Opera 9.0 and Flash 9.0
(which I use only with Opera). This box is really fast, and the gigabit
is part of it. Web sites seem to load twice as fast as they do on the
laptop, which is also 64-bit but only 10/100. Feisty uses
2.6.20-15-generic #2 SMP kernel on this box.

The only problem remaining with Feisty is the poweroff problem that I
have discussed here at length. I have finally tracked down what is
happening, I just don't know yet exactly what the cause is. What
happens is I get a sudden power off as though I pulled the power cable
out of the back of the machine. The first time this happened was when I
was formatting a 238 GB partition that had been part of /dev/md3, a
RAID 1 array. The array got goobered up and I was trying to fix it.
E2fsck found a lot of errors on the lost partition, but before running
e2fsck on it I tried just mkfs. After a few minutes of formatting I got
the power off. But that is the only time I ever got a power off from
formatting. I abandoned the formatting, deleted and then recreated the
partition, and then added the partition with "mdadm
-a /dev/md3 /dev/sdb4." At that point it started "recovering," and a
few minutes later I got another power off.

Later I deleted both 238 GB partitions and the array, then recreated
the partitions and the array. I deleted/recreated the partitions in
Gparted and in the process set them first to unformatted, then set the
RAID flag. Then I used mdadm --create to set them up as a RAID 1 array.
All this went just fine. The problem is that after mdadm says it has
created the array it then has to sync the partitions. For a 238 GB
array it estimated this would take 99 minutes. I have never gotten
close. I get a power off no later than six minutes into it, sometimes
within seconds of starting.

The problem is that once you create the array mdadm has the array
marked as "needing to be synced" and it will commence the syncing all
by itself as soon as you boot an operating system, even a rescue CD. So
Feisty boots and runs fine now, but if I forget to do mdadm -S /dev/md3
to stop the array right after booting I will get a power off within a
few minutes.

What is causing this? Well, the hard drives are two identical Western
Digital 320 GB SATA II drives. I note that I did create three other
RAID 1 arrays just fine, a 2 GB swap, a 40 GB Feisty, and a 20 GB
(fromerly) Etch. The difference is that all three were created by an
install utility, not directly by mdadm (but does the install utility
call mdadm?) and all three are much smaller. Is either fact
significant? I don't know and I haven't had time to do much sleuthing.
I do know the drives are on the SATA connectors on the motherboard and
the chipset is nVidia 405 with a Phoenix-Award BIOS. The BIOS is the
latest available. Is it in the controller? Is it in mdadm? Is it in
sata-nv? All I know is that it cannot be heat and the power supply and
the motherboard have both been replaced with no change in the problem.
I've been too busy to tackle it any further, but fixing it is near the
top of my list.

I don't have any idea what made Feisty lock up on installation. It
certainly can't be the CPU. And if everything else installed OK, then
it doesn't sound like a hardware fault. Must be a missing driver for
something that every other distro is able to load or at least ignore.

I'd also suggest giving Fedora 7 a shot. I was very impressed with it,
and that was with test2. Besides, it's fun to install new distros. :)

On Sun, May 06, 2007 at 11:26:41AM -0700, m0gely wrote:
> This assumes you truly understand where function and form meet, and can 
...
> Of course, the above is opinion and I don't claim to be an authority on 

What he said.  

Also, you should read the second (or later) edition of the book
"Don't Make Me Think" by Steve Krug.  I have given these as presents to
my web designer friends, who then bought copies for the rest of their
companies.  It won't make a web designer out of you, but will teach you
some things to look for when you choose the web designer you spend $1500
on.

The message of the book is "put stuff where your user expects it" so
they don't have to work too hard.  The users and browsers are becoming
more educated, and most people's connections are getting faster, so
the dominant paradigm shifts over time.  Hence the emphasis on the
latest edition.

For an E-commerce site, Krug's favorite is Amazon.  Think about
how big the Bezos empire is becoming, and you have an empirical
verification of Krug's opinion.  Krug says why Amazon and other
sites work, and that is the part you can apply to your own goals.

"... Think" is a spendy little paperback, but it is a pleasant read.

Keith

> I'll have a clean kernel, etc., on the Gentoo side. But meanwhile it looks 
> like CentOS is the horse to beat.

Everything I read on google in the last 10 minutes indicates that
there are many gentoo users running this CPU.  There's more to kernel
happiness than the CPU choice.  I would lay suspicion on the video
card first (assuming none of the hardware is clinically ill).  Do you
have an ATI Radeon video card?  I can get one of those to freeze a
machine.

Try the ubuntu installer in text mode, if that choice is offered.  If
it doesn't freeze in text mode, that points to the video card.  I'd
bet that's why you could get debian installed (is the debian installer
still text-only?).

I always have to install redhat ES 4 in text mode on IBM 346's, which
come with an ATI Radeon card.  And I have to add "nolapic" to the
kernel command line until I can get into the running redhat load and
change the video driver to vesa in xorg.conf.  Then I remove
"nolapic".  Even when using the vesa driver on the 346, I get
occasional freeze-ups (not cool in a server).  The new IBM server
which replaces the 346 (I forgot its model number) has a newer ATI
card (not a Radeon), and I've seen no freeze-ups yet.  The new server
is 64-bit, by the way, but it's Intel.  I have yet to install gentoo
on one of these, and I probably won't get to, because the corporate
entity where I work won't consider gentoo for servers.

The kernel that is running when you boot from a gentoo install CD has
nothing to do with the kernel that you build for your installation.
And the age of the gentoo CD has nothing to do with the newness of the
packages you install.  If a gentoo CD doesn't run, use a CD that does.
There's no requirement that you need a gentoo CD to install gentoo.  I
always use knoppix.  Or install centos and use it for your host
environment, and install gentoo on a second hard drive, and make it
the first hard drive when done.

What does your lspci look like?

Carlos Konstanski

I'll reply with the CORRECT email address this time:

Is this an HP because I've had different troubles with two HP systems 
running Ubuntu (Kubuntu on one)? I also had trouble with OpenSuSE 10.3 
(various versions of Alpha) and 10.2.

I found that by running with /noapic nolapic pci=routeirq/ allowed 
installation on the one system (an HP Laptop - DV6253) giving me the 
most problems.

You might see if some combination of those parameters allow it to load. 
Based upon looking up my model, and related models, HP changed something 
in their chipset that was giving various Linux distros issues.

logging on to machine B from machine A in such a way as to be able to
run X-windows programs on machine B, but see then on machine A?

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon May  7 09:50:56 2007
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 7 May 2007 09:50:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] X on another machine
In-Reply-To: <463F5446.2060207@comcast.net>
References: <463F5446.2060207@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0705070945250.20021@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 7 May 2007, Richard C. Steffens wrote:

> I understand how to log on to machine B from machine A via ssh to give me
> command line access to machine B, but what do you call the concept of
> logging on to machine B from machine A in such a way as to be able to run
> X-windows programs on machine B, but see then on machine A?

Dick,

   In /etc/ssh/sshd_config uncomment 'X11Forwarding yes'.

   In /etc/ssh/ssh_config uncomment 'ForwardX11 yes'.

   Then, on machine A type 'ssh -X user at machine.B.com' and -- once logged in
-- run your application.

   See:
<http://www.cyberciti.biz/tips/running-x-window-graphical-application-over-ssh-session.html>

Rich

--

Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc.        |          Accelerator(TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>     Voice: 503-667-4517      Fax: 503-667-8863


From gilmanhunt at comcast.net  Mon May  7 09:52:00 2007
From: gilmanhunt at comcast.net (Russ Gilman-Hunt (YAR))
Date: Mon, 7 May 2007 09:52:00 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] X on another machine
In-Reply-To: <463F5446.2060207@comcast.net>
References: <463F5446.2060207@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20070507095200.0bdacd01@badger.had1.or.comcast.net.>


On Mon, 07 May 2007 09:31:02 -0700
"Richard C. Steffens" <rsteff at comcast.net> wrote:

> I understand how to log on to machine B from machine A via ssh to give
> me command line access to machine B, but what do you call the concept
> of logging on to machine B from machine A in such a way as to be able
> to run X-windows programs on machine B, but see then on machine A?
> 

Personally, I call it "magic" ...

Given that both systems have the X software installed, if you ssh from
A to B with the flags "-X -A", if sshd_config on B allows X11
forwarding, you can run X programs on B like "gvim file" and have the
window pop up on A.

I can do it from here to a system I develop on in Houston, but the
resulting gvim window is less responsive than a "normal" terminal
window. Your mileage may vary. 

-- 
Russ Gilman-Hunt
http://www.arghwebworks.com/
gilmanhunt at comcast.net

From ladyfractal at yahoo.com  Mon May  7 10:20:53 2007

On Monday 07 May 2007 09:31:02 Richard Rich:

The term you're looking for is 'Remote X-windows' usually shortened to 'Remote 
X'.  The easiest way to do this is ssh -X <user>@<host>. That sets up a X 
tunnel and you (usually) don't have to worry about doing DISPLAY=IP:0.0; 
export DISPLAY.

Cheers
Aj

> I've checked to be sure output isn't muted in KMix, and that level
> controls are somewhere other than all the way down. I've also checked to
> make sure the speakers are turned on, and plugged in to the correct
> output jack on the back of the card.
>
> Any other ideas?
>

An old trick I always used to test audio was to cat a .wav file to
/dev/dsp.  (It has to be an uncompressed audio file--an mp3/ogg or
flac won't necessarily make noise.)  If it works, then the problem is
in user-space.

--Rogan

Quentin Hartman wrote:
> If you're determined to try to save it, download a copy the Ultimate Boot
> Disk and run the MHDD tool that it has on the drive. It will have to be
> on a
> "real" IDE controller for it to work, not a USB enclosure, but if you run
> the surface scan and remap (if it can run) it might be able to let you
> salvage some data. I've used MHDD to bring a number of drives back from the
> brink. In fact, I have a formerly "bad" HDD running in my laptop right now.
> Did a forced remap of a few sectors and it's been rock solid for over a
> year.

the 13 GB drive to the "new" 330 MHz machine that will replace the old

else with the machines at the time, so I didn't mind.

I found this instruction at:

http://alsa.opensrc.org/Using_alsactl_to_preserve_volume_state

I realize I need to restore the settings when the sound driver is
loaded, such as at boot time. Here is what is said:

--------------------------------------------------------------
   # load/unload the volume settings on startup/shutdown
   post-install snd-driver-name /usr/sbin/alsactl restore
   pre-remove snd-driver-name /usr/sbin/alsactl store
--------------------------------------------------------------

That's great. But, what do I put in place of snd-driver-name? There are
several drivers listed with lsmod that begin with snd. The one that
seems most obvious is snd-mixer-oss, but that's just a guess.

From ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com  Mon May  7 20:15:27 2007
From: ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Mon, 7 May 2007 21:15:27 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] X on another machine
In-Reply-To: <463F5446.2060207@comcast.net>
References: <463F5446.2060207@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0705072043560.7006@sphinktoo.pippiandcarlos.com>

On Mon, 7 May 2007, Richard C. Steffens wrote:

> Date: Mon, 07 May 2007 09:31:02 -0700
> From: Richard C. Steffens <rsteff at comcast.net>
> Reply-To: "General Linux/UNIX discussion and help;	civil and on-topic"
>     <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
> To: PLUG List <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
> Subject: [PLUG] X on another machine
> 
> I understand how to log on to machine B from machine A via ssh to give
> me command line access to machine B, but what do you call the concept of
> logging on to machine B from machine A in such a way as to be able to
> run X-windows programs on machine B, but see then on machine A?
>
> -- 
> Regards,
>
> Dick Steffens

No one has mentioned XDMCP yet.  When you use XDMCP to gain a remote X
session, it is exactly as if you were sitting at the console of the
host.  The only difference is that the monitor, keyboard and mouse you
are using happen to be connected to some other machine.  Hummingbird
uses XDMCP.  You can accomplish the same thing with cygwin for free.

This is not a replacement for the immensely useful ssh X forwarding
method already outlined.  This is for those special times when you
want an entire desktop on the host, not just a single app.

A picture is worth a thousand words.  Here's how to do it.  "Client"
is tha machine you're physically sitting at, and "host" is the remote
machine to which you'll be connecting.  The assumption is made that
you are using gdmlogin as your login manager:

- Firewall!  TCP ports 6000, 6001 (and more if you have more than two
   X displays), and UPD port 177, should be blocked from the WAN.  But
   these ports need to be accessible on the LAN.

- Set up the client for at least two X displays.  This allows you to
   have a local desktop on one display, and a remote connection on the
   other.  Do this by launching gdmsetup as root, clicking on the
   "Security" tab, clicking the "Configure X server" button, and adding
   a second "Standard" server to the list.  Close, log out, and restart
   X.  You should see 2 login screens appear, one after the other, with
   a moment of blank screen in between.

- Configure the host to allow XDMCP connections.  Start by ssh-ing
   with the -XY switches to the host as root and launching gdmsetup.
   Click on the "Remote" tab, then click the "Configure XDMCP" button,
   and check the "Honor indirect requests" checkbox.  Exit gdmsetup,
   then restart X on the host.

- Connect!  Switch over to your spare X display.  Fish around between
   CTRL-ALT-F7, F8 and F9 until you find the one.  Click on "Actions"
   and then "Remote login via XDMCP".  After a few seconds, you should
   get a list of available servers on your network.  If the host is
   listed, double-click it.  This will connect you to the host and
   present you with its login screen.  If you connect to a Solaris
   host, for example, you'll get the death CDE prompt.

Carlos Konstanski

If your system uses Terminfo rather than termcap (most modern systems

installed, or if the newer version is not visible to the Emacs

So, scanning for differences, the most significant ones for you are
the termcap.h and term.h.  On debian, those are found in the
libncurses5-dev package.  That won't give you X11 support, but it
should solve the terminal stuff.

Also, consulting the debian package's build dependencies, I find this:

 mailx, libncurses5-dev, texinfo, liblockfile-dev, libungif4-dev, libtiff4-dev | libtiff-dev, xaw3dg-dev, libpng3-dev, libjpeg62-dev, autotools-dev, dpkg-dev (>> 1.10.0), quilt, debhelper (>= 4), libxaw7-dev, sharutils

I think you can get away without mailx, quilt, dpkg-dev or debhelper,
but the others are probably useful and/or desirable.  So try this:

 $ sudo apt-get install libncurses5-dev texinfo liblockfile-dev libungif4-dev libtiff-dev xaw3dg-dev libpng3-dev libjpeg62-dev autotools-dev libxaw7-dev sharutils

and rerun configure, etc.


-- 
Russell Senior, Secretary
russell at personaltelco.net

On 5/8/07, Denis Heidtmann <denish at dslnorthwest.net> wrote:
>
> If Gaim is automatically run by KDE during boot, any attempt to use it
> causes it
> go instantly close.  (My standard test is to right click on an entry in
> the
> buddy list.) Top shows Gaim as running when the session starts, but it
> goes away
> when I perform the right click. Restarting Gaim from the K menu works
> fine, and
> no more problems occur during that session.


Disclaimer: I'm not a KDE user, so this idea may be totally wrong

I've seen problems similar to happen when a program starts to early in
session initialization and some of the environment variables and whatnot
that it is expecting to see haven't been setup yet. Granted this was on
Gnome, and a _long_ time ago. But, you might want to see if you can have it
start later in the session setup and see if that helps. As I said though, I
don't even know if KDE has a mechanism to do this, but I would assume that
they do...

Yea, I know about howtoforge.com there are a lot of great articles up
there but One of the things I know I love about Linux is the choice, if we
made everyone do things only one way we would be Microsoft. So maybe what
I'm offering doesn't need to be something more, maybe it's just another
choice, like the choice of Fedora, CentOS, Whitebox, RHEL, all basically
the same, with slight differences to give people a choice.

There are things that are different on my site, I really try and cater to
my users needs, they can contact me if they want something there that
isn't there, if they want something changed, if they just want to ask a
question, using the contact us forum, e-mailing me, posting on the blogs,
using the IRC chat board, I guess i'm trying to offer a touch of humanity.

I'm adding video howto's that can be found on the site, i offer
screenshots, i try to stick to a standard, some people just might like my
way of writing the howto's it's simple and to the point.

information.

Rich Shepard wrote:

I never did find anything that said specifically to "use this driver
name", so I just went with my guess and it works. Here are the lines I
added to /etc/modules.conf on my Slackware 11.0 machine:

# Added 7 May 2007 to try to get the sound mixer settings right at boot
time.
# load/unload the volume settings on startup/shutdown
post-install snd-mixer-oss /usr/sbin/alsactl restore
pre-remove snd-mixer-oss /usr/sbin/alsactl store

I'm don't have a lot of experience with Java so that this for what it is worth.
I have tried on two different occasions to get cruisecontrol up and
running.  Once I got
it to show web pages but it was too difficult for me to configure the
projects all of which
were not Java based.

When I started at my current company I looked again at these type of
systems.  I tried
three different ones (actually more but the others didn't have the feature set
needed) selected from this web site
http://damagecontrol.codehaus.org/Continuous+Integration+Server+Feature+Matrix

luntbuild
bettlejuice
pulse

For me,the major hassle of getting these up and running was getting
the Sun Java SDK
installed correctly on Fedora.  The next step was finding the
necessary environment
variables that were expected to allow the program to find and use java.

The simplest method I found to getting Java setup for these programs
was to just place
a copy locally for the program since I was going to use a specific
user for doing the builds
anyway.

luntbuild - manual setup, manual project configuration, manual
administration.  Never was
able to get a project configured.
Bettlejuice came with it own embedded version of java so that issue
was removed but
it wanted to be installed in a specific location running as root.
Configuring projects was not intuitive mostly manual.

We eventually settled on pulse.  Getting this setup and running after
the experience of
doing the others was simple.  Once I got a project up and working,  I
could turn over
the admin of the server to a manager.  It was that simple to use.

And here I thought you had gotten the automated mailer working

As Rich said, you can pipe to `mail` or `sendmail`.  If you're in Perl, 
there are libraries which do that and even some which do SMTP directly 
with varying sorts of authentication, relay support, etc.  The 
advantage of using a library which directly supports the protocol is 
pretty clear if you need it to also run on qdos and such.  Of course, 
it could also be good to gloss over the issues of varying distros and 
mis-configured sendmails.  The disadvantage is of course that sysadmins 
with properly configured sendmails will be annoyed by your program 
requiring them to re-type their configuration.

From ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com  Wed May  9 15:19:13 2007
From: ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Wed, 9 May 2007 16:19:13 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] can one email from within a program?
In-Reply-To: <132822013.1178742747934.JavaMail.root@fepweb14>
References: <132822013.1178742747934.JavaMail.root@fepweb14>
Message-ID: <40659.127.0.0.1.1178749153.squirrel@webmail.pippiandcarlos.com>

> Being an old guy, I remember mail and mh ... but lately all I've used are
> GUI mailers. With clients like thunderbird or evolution or eudora, can
> people send mail from within programs. I'm looking at the command line

> the command line with some options.

> Can one use an email client to send mail without popping up any windows
> that require user action?
>
> Thanks.
>  -Ted

Here's a perl function that will do as Rich suggested (i.e. opening a pipe
to a mailer program).  The body is passed in as a string.  For tightest
security, it is best to hardcode the recipient at minimum.  If the
recipient were a function argument, it would be more possible for a hacker
to exploit the function as a mass mailer.  With a hardcoded recipient, it
can only spam one person.

sub send_mail {
    my $body = pop(@_);
    my $to = $SENDER;
    my $from = $RECIPIENT;
    my $subject = $SUBJECT;
    my $sendmail = "/usr/lib/sendmail -t -oi -f $to";
    open(MAIL, " |$sendmail") || die "Can't start sendmail: $!";
    print MAIL "From: $from\n";
    print MAIL "To: $to\n";
    print MAIL "Subject: $subject\n";
    print MAIL $body;
    close(MAIL);
}

Carlos Konstanski



From jonscully at gmail.com  Wed May  9 16:02:46 2007

>From a term prompt:

[jack at localhost]$ echo -e "See attached file.\rHave a great day!\r" |
mutt -s "Latest release" -a file.tar.gz joe at domain.org

This sends an e-mail with subject "Latest release".  The body, "See
attached...", is piped and a gzip'ed file is attached (i.e. mutt does
it all).

From scratchcomputing at gmail.com  Wed May  9 16:48:27 2007
From: scratchcomputing at gmail.com (Eric Wilhelm)
Date: Wed, 9 May 2007 16:48:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] can one email from within a program?
In-Reply-To: <40659.127.0.0.1.1178749153.squirrel@webmail.pippiandcarlos.com>

# from Carlos Konstanski
# on Wednesday 09 May 2007 03:19 pm:

>Here's a perl function that will do as Rich suggested (i.e. opening a
> pipe to a mailer program). ?The body is passed in as a string. ?For
> tightest security, it is best to hardcode the recipient at minimum.

You probably also want to use the list form of pipe open or else you'll 
have to quote the $to value to keep the shell from breaking it into 
multiple arguments (not to mention that whole $to="hah;rm -rf /" 
thing.)  Of course, Email::Send::Sendmail has that same bug (though it 
gets irony points for going to the extra effort of creating this bug by 
flattening a list @args.)  To be fair, perl has only had list-form pipe 
open() for something like 5 years now.

I suspect that your code also has a hole in that it doesn't finalize the 
headers before printing the body.  Email::Simple would solve that.

--Eric

# from alan
# on Wednesday 09 May 2007 03:03 pm:

>I wonder if the Perl code that emulates SMTP actually works with sites
>that use Greylisting. ?Does the Perl SMTP code actually queue and
> resend?

Net::SMTP actually implements (at least partly) the protocol, so I 
wouldn't call it emulation.

It doesn't appear to provide much error handling though, so I think if 
you want to build a proper daemon, you'll have to get your fingers 
dirty.

Maybe better luck with Net::ESMTP or Net::SMTP::Retryable?

Mail::Mailer does appear to get the sendmail thing right.  Anyway the 
general rule is that anything on CPAN labeled ::Simple or ::Easy is at 
least partly ::Wrong or ::Broken.

Perl might be too dangerous a way to send mail for lightweights like
me, given its close interface to shell commands.  It made for a good
example, as it illustrates the problem so nicely.  I wasn't even
trying; I thought my function was relatively secure!  I co-opted it
from old-school perl hackers I used to work with.  Since I'm not using
this function anywhere right now, I'm delighted by Eric's audit.

Using a trusted library is a better move, since the codebase is more
likely to have been scrutinized by many talented coders.  But Eric
shows that there is room for false security here.  One must audit the
code oneself to be sure, and even that is subject to the examiner's
skill.

Perhaps it makes sense to find out which language Ted is using, and
then find the least exploitable means to send email in his language.
If anybody knows the best way to send mail from a common lisp program,
by the way, I am all ears.

Carlos Konstanski

> they do...
> 
The problem Gaim launch is precipitated by either telling KDE to restore the 
previous session, or telling KDE to save the current session.  I would be 
surprised if there is a way to influence when KDE does the restore during 
session initialization.

I believe there are other ways to launch applications on starting a session, but 
I do not know what they are.  My impression is that there are many ways.

One thing I notice is that in the Kmenu System Settings there is a tab for 
"Default Applications".  On that window the Instant Messenger is shown as 
Kopete.  There is a drop-down list, but only Kopete is on the list.  Adept shows 
Kopete as installed.  Should I uninstall it? (A long time ago I tried Kopete but 
found it inadequate for various reasons.)

-Denis

From tkubaska at charter.net  Thu May 10 02:11:33 2007
From: tkubaska at charter.net (tkubaska at charter.net)
Date: Thu, 10 May 2007 2:11:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] can one email from within a program?
Message-ID: <454827282.1178788293511.JavaMail.root@fepweb14>

> Perhaps it makes sense to find out which language Ted is using, and then find 
> the least exploitable means to send email in his language.

We're still thinking about this. What we have now are some lines in the config.xml used by CruiseControl that sends mail when a build occurs and a build occurs whenever there is a cvs checkin.

I have Postfix running on the build box (the advice I got here tells me I don't really need a dedicated mail server, just a client ... I can use the mail server the rest of the network uses).

We want to make it better and are looking at http://phpmailer.sourceforge.net
I hadn't known about mutt ... I think it's cool. Thanks for the great responses.

FYI, here's the blurb in config.xml that sends the mail
      <htmlemail mailhost="halibut"
        returnaddress="ted at halibut"
        defaultsuffix="@halibut"
        buildresultsurl="http://localhost:8080/cruisecontrol/buildresults/dms"
        css="/home/ted/docs/css/cruisecontrol.css"
        xsldir="/opt/cruisecontrol-2.6.2/reporting/jsp/webcontent/xsl"
        logdir="logs/dms">

        <map alias="ted" address="ted at halibut" />

        <always address="ted" />
        <failure address="ted" reportWhenFixed="true" />

      </htmlemail>

 -Ted


From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu May 10 03:17:10 2007
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Thu, 10 May 2007 03:17:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: can one email from within a program?
References: <132822013.1178742747934.JavaMail.root@fepweb14>
	<40659.127.0.0.1.1178749153.squirrel@webmail.pippiandcarlos.com>
Message-ID: <86fy652dax.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Carlos" == Carlos Konstanski <ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com> writes:

Carlos> Here's a perl function that will do as Rich suggested (i.e. opening a pipe
Carlos> to a mailer program).  The body is passed in as a string.  For tightest
Carlos> security, it is best to hardcode the recipient at minimum.  If the
Carlos> recipient were a function argument, it would be more possible for a hacker
Carlos> to exploit the function as a mass mailer.  With a hardcoded recipient, it
Carlos> can only spam one person.

Carlos> sub send_mail {
Carlos>     my $body = pop(@_);
Carlos>     my $to = $SENDER;
Carlos>     my $from = $RECIPIENT;
Carlos>     my $subject = $SUBJECT;
Carlos>     my $sendmail = "/usr/lib/sendmail -t -oi -f $to";
Carlos>     open(MAIL, " |$sendmail") || die "Can't start sendmail: $!";
Carlos>     print MAIL "From: $from\n";
Carlos>     print MAIL "To: $to\n";
Carlos>     print MAIL "Subject: $subject\n";
Carlos>     print MAIL $body;
Carlos>     close(MAIL);
Carlos> }

As coded, if I can provide $SENDER or $SUBJECT, I can also spam people.

Please don't invoke sendmail this way.  From Perl, there are safer
alternatives.

Dan Young wrote:
> On 5/6/07, M. Edward (Ed) Borasky <znmeb at cesmail.net> wrote:
>> No ... what's different about Fedora is corporate support. The forums
>> are public, the processes are open, the innovation is rapid, etc. for
>> Debian, Gentoo, and CentOS as well.
>
> Debian is rapidly innovating?
>
> CentOS is repackaging what Red Hat provides. A great community
> service, but hardly innovation.
>
Both Debian and CentOS are tributaries of the same open source river. 
You really have to compare Fedora with Debian "sid", not "etch", which 
is where I started.

In any event, my initial goal in choosing Etch and CentOS 5 was to test 
the latest "stable" distros on brand-new hardware. As it turned out, 
neither was stable enough to use. As luck would have it, Gentoo released 
2007.0 on Monday and the machine is more or less up and running. The x86 
(32-bit) version hasn't hiccupped yet, which I think exonerates the bulk 
of the hardware. The x86_64/AMD64 version is flaky but better than Etch 
or CentOS. And it looks like there are some things that require a more 
recent kernel -- Gentoo's 2.6.19 is better than the 2.6.18 in Etch and 
CentOS, and Gentoo's 2.6.20 is better still. I'm running their 2.4.21 
kernel problem-free on my other two boxes, which are 32-bit, so it's 
probably going to get put into the new box as well. Then at least I'll 
have something I feel comfortable filing bugs against. :)

Gentoo is probably the best distro for people who are, like me, in the 
process of kernel/hardware testing. Most of the other distros have 
created monstrous kernels that attempt to support every piece of gear 
one could possibly own and don't really make it *easy* to recompile a 
kernel. Debian at least provides the capability of rebuilding kernels, 
although I couldn't figure it out the other day.
