From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sat May 19 21:38:58 2007
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sat, 19 May 2007 21:38:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] USB2 to P-ATA drive interfaces (useful data)
Message-ID: <20070520043858.GA10469@gate.kl-ic.com>


I am moving my backup server from 2.4.22 to 2.6.18 (quite a leap!).  I
use hard drives for backup - with dirvish (www.dirvish.org) of course!

The later 2.4.xx kernels allowed parallel ATA hard drives to be hot
swapped, the 2.6.xx kernels do not.  Backup hard drives should be
swapped regularly to protect against power faults or enemy action.
I need a swapping alternative - external USB2 enclosures, or swap
trays with USB2 interfaces, are one way to do that.

Not all USB2 to PATA interfaces work correctly with Linux.  Some 
don't work at all, some generate intermittent faults or lockups at
long intervals, some are slow.  I can write 30MB/s to a directly 
connected PATA drive.  The fastest USB2 to PATA interfaces write
20MB/s, and the slowest write 11MB/s .  

I found 10 different systems;  3 enclosures, 3 swap cages, and 4
smart cables.  Most are based on Cypress or Genesys chipsets.  Two
supposedly identical swap cages had different chipsets and different
performance. I got 7 systems to work, 5 tolerably quickly.  A newer
2.6.21 kernel on a Yoper Live CD fared no better on the fastest,
the slowest, or the non-working systems.  I am told that 2.6.21 has
significant improvements to the USB2 code, but I did not see that in
my results.

I did not try any of the external integrated drives. 

The best performance came from Cypress CY7C68300, CY7C68301, CY7C68320,
and CY7C68321 family of chips.  Before you buy any USB2 drives or
interfaces, you should Google to find out what chipset they use.  Note
that older Cypress chip sets, such as the C768013, can lock up your
kernel.  The Genesys GL811E family usually work, but are 33% slower;
however, I had one dead one.  Stay away from JMicron.
 
More information on the wiki at www.dirvish.org/cgi.bin?USB2Drives .
Feel free to add pointers to your own test data on that page.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993

Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

mod_macro (http://www.cri.ensmp.fr/~coelho/mod_macro/) looks like 
just the thing - and in my case I can encapsulate the IP addresses
in macros.

Unfortunately, it requires recompiling httpd, which interferes with
yum upgrades of the main httpd code.  The "m4" approach that Paul
suggested will work without changing httpd, but I would have to make
sure that everyone connected with the system worked through the m4
macro process, rather than directly editing httpd.conf .  I third
approach would be to build a Perl script with some embedded HERE
documents.

I will probably go the m4 route for now (I've used m4 since 1981, 3BSD
on a vax 11/780 ), but I will code with an eye towards mod_macro,
which I hope will become part of the main httpd package soon, which
means I can use an upgradable httpd with macro capability.

I do :)

I frequently test suspend/resume and wol functionality of e100. If you have 
found a bug or an issue, please take it to our list 
(e1000-devel at lists.sourceforge.net) or file a bugreport. Currently I am not 
aware of any bugs with e100 in recent kernels (2.6.20/21). The driver is very 
stable, there are not many fixes going in.

for clarification, we have basically 2 versions of the same driver code. One 
lives inside the mainline kernel git tree at kernel.org, and the other is 
standalone and has compatibility code glue to make it work on all older kernels 
(down to 2.4.20 or so). We do this for all our network drivers (e100, e1000, ixgb).

hth,

Auke

immediately obvious, I go look in the books and on the web for directions.

I would be happy to offer sample .pinerc and .vm files, for pine and
emacs-vm, respectively.  It helps to have a working environment to
start.  Are you trying to connect to a POP3 or an IMAP server?
There are different configs for each.

Emacs is a chore to learn.  It took me a month to become proficient,
and that was with a total-immersion crash program (eschewed eclipse
for emacs-jde at my paying job!)  But I wasn't just learning emacs; I
was also learning ecb, jde and xrefactory.  Learning emacs in its raw
form would probably be no worse than learning vim.  Mixing the two, by
way, is still interesting to this day, given their very different
keystrokes.

Your real question, which was whether there are workshops in the
Portland area, is unknown to me, an Idaho resident.

As for the distro path one takes in life, and its resultant effects on
ones learning: I doubt there are many gnu/linux users who jump
directly into gentoo or even vanilla debian on Day One.  Personally, I
started with redhat 8, and stayed with redhat into 9, before moving to
debian.  I experienced at that point what you must be experiencing
now.  I utilized kwrite for all my text editing instead of vim, for
example.  I had to learn how to manage my system without all those
system-config-whatever GUIs.  But it felt good to make the move.  A
year later, the move to gentoo felt good too.  What's next, I wonder?

I was very lucky to have a pair of gnu/linux gurus in my workplace who
offered up many hours of their time toward the goal of helping me
become productive in gnu/linux.  Their efforts culminated in showing
me how to teach myself stuff with google and man pages.  Google is
what eventually led me to this list, where I found the smartest people
in the most gnu/linux-saturated area of the country.  Thanks for
letting me hang out.

Carlos Konstanski

Not sure how many of you made it to this, but it was cool.  Lots of
interesting stuff.  Found a source for USB to 3.3V serial converters
(useful for hacking linux wireless access points).

One of the cool, unexpected things was an amateur balloonist that
travelled from Boise.  He launches small payloads to "near space",
circa 100k feet altitude with weather balloon type vehicles.  Does
stuff like take photos, measure temperature or radiation, etc.  At a
particular altitude, the balloon bursts and plummets back to the
ground where amateur packet radio telemetry reports gps location for
recovery.

Sounded like a lot of fun.  Those of you that missed it are truly
misser-outers.

From plug at merlot.com  Sun May 20 20:54:41 2007
From: plug at merlot.com (Kurt Sussman)
Date: Sun, 20 May 2007 20:54:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] deep philosophical question
Message-ID: <20070521035441.GS12172@merlot.com>

I spent a few days at RailsConf, and learned a ton. But it was a little
frustrating watching the Mac users... Macs just work. Sleep, hibernate,
wifi, Textmate, Quicksilver, it all just works.

I'm planning to buy a new laptop around the end of the year even though
my 4 year old Dell runs Ubuntu just fine. Because sometimes the wifi just
won't hook up, and sleep has never worked under any distro, and the
display blows out every year like clockwork (warrantees are great!).
But there's nothing like Textmate on any platform. Except the Mac.

So there's the freedom issue; Linux is free and OSX isn't. I like
freedom, and I'm willing to do my part to keep it, but at what point do
I just use the best tool for the job and assuage my guilt by working on
free server apps?

Yes, Macs cost more than the basic Linux-capable PC. But if it saves me
30 minutes per day (which is pretty conservative, I think), it will take
me 20 days of paid work to make up the difference. So is it really more
expensive?

I'm used to Linux, my servers run Linux, it will save space in my brain
to use only one OS, I don't like the 'one menubar to rule them all'
thing, etc. Or are those excuses to keep doing the same sub-optimal
thing?

Your thoughts, please?

--Kurt

    Merlot Research Group, Inc               http://www.merlot.com
    kls[at]merlot.com        GPG key 82505A74       GTalk: ratbelt

From qhartman at gmail.com  Sun May 20 21:36:02 2007
From: qhartman at gmail.com (Quentin Hartman)
Date: Sun, 20 May 2007 21:36:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] deep philosophical question
In-Reply-To: <20070521035441.GS12172@merlot.com>
References: <20070521035441.GS12172@merlot.com>
Message-ID: <8975a95f0705202136p3a75812dl9f82d3cbb76d44a8@mail.gmail.com>

On 5/20/07, Kurt Sussman <plug at merlot.com> wrote:
>
> Your thoughts, please?
>

I had a similar thought a few years ago, and I got a G4 iBook. The big OSX
experiment. It was nice, a lot of the fighting I did with Redhat on the
previous laptop was gone. I used it wuite happily for about 6 months. After
that time, I sat down and really objectively evaluated my usage profile. I
discovered that nearly everything I used on there was a Linux native
application that I had either installed using Fink (not painless!) or was
repackaged for OSX. There were a few exceptions, a couple native apps I had
come to enjoy, but nothing I couldn't live without. I also discovered that
even after 6 months I never managed to get completely comfortable with the
UI paradigm. It tended to get in my way more than I liked, and there were
certain things that I expected to be able to do easily, but were cumbersome
since it was Unixish, emphasis on the "ish". This made it harder for me to
figure things out when they went sideways. Yes, don't believe the hype,
things do go sideways on Macs. A good friend of mine is battling his iBook
regularly, though not as often as he battles his Windows desktop. But that's
another discussion.

So I dubbed the OSX experiment a conditional failure, and decided to install
Gentoo on it. All that discomfort went away, and I discovered that Gentoo
was not only better for me than OSX, it was better than Redhat had been pre
iBook.

Flash-forward to today. I abandoned Gentoo (too time intensive, and too
prone to breakage on upgrades) and am now a solid Ubuntero. For me, using
OSX was less efficient for me than Linux, but through it, I discovered that
there was a much better distro for me out there too. In full retrospect, I'd
call that a net win, but not due to any particularly great attribute of OSX.

As far as your comments regarding hardware support, my wireless (a store
brand Atheros based card) "just works", and I don't use hibernate.

But yeah, I'd love to be able to use textmate.... ;)

-- 
-Regards-

-Quentin Hartman-

On 5/20/07, Quentin Hartman <qhartman at gmail.com> wrote:
> I had a similar thought a few years ago, and I got a G4 iBook. The big OSX

I want to second both Quentin and Eric's comments.  I did the OSX
thing on a 12" g4 iBook for a year, after being a hard-core linux
user, and ended up on Ubuntu as well.  Ubuntu "just works" as long as
you don't delve to far out from what is expected.. (eg: power
management may go out the window if you decide not to use the gnome,
kde or xfce-desktop packages.) Compared to OS X though, ubuntu "just
works" better.

Every OS upgrade broke my keylayout and emacs installs, and I tried
everything I could find -- emacs in a terminal, cocoa emacs, emacs via
darwin ports, emacs via fink, emacs from source.... (in case it's not
obvious, I'm not into textmate ;)

The filesystem's bizarre philosophy about maintaining case, but
ignoring it would have cost me close to 6 months on my MS Thesis, but
it was in cvs on a different machine (and being backed up).  I did
loose about 4 gigs of unimportant content though.  (Largely because I
didn't realize I had overwritten my documents directory in time to
revert to backups.)

I eventually switched to a T42p and the default ubuntu install gave me
everything I was using on the Mac, and the ability to customize to my
heart's content, when I wanted to.  (and the hardware has been
rock-solid for 2 years)

In my experience, Linux on a Dell is a nightmare -- I've heard of
Linux working well on Dells, but I've never witnessed anything but
frustration in that arena. I'd guess things will improve when Dell
starts shipping laptops with Linux though.

--Rogan

The Intel-based Macs do have hardware virtualization support, and
therefore you can run whatever else you want on them concurrently.
So, for example I currently have Ubuntu and Fedora on mine, running
under the beta VMware Fusion.  You could also install a Microsoft OS
on it if you wanted, or Solaris.

The Macs are expensive, no doubt about it, but at the moment they are
the only option that you can run all those OS environments on
simultaneously.  Doing some comparisons I guesstimated the difference
between a Mac and a comparable laptop from someone else to be about
$200.  The hardware you get with a Mac tends to be top of the line.
Just something to think about when you're talking about productivity.
Bootcamp also provides the option of dual-booting.

I do agree with some of the other folks that the OSX environment is
somewhat like a mutilated BSD.  Running open-source apps under the X11
server you lose some of the so-called elegance of the OSX environment
(the menubar comes to mind).  And I miss having more than one button
on the trackpad.  On the other hand, I love the dashboard.  What would
I do each day without my Chuck Norris Facts widget?

"When Chuck Norris does division, there are no remainders."

Jason

freedom (variation and all) more palatable.

# from Russell Senior

>("too many variations", et al). ?

Yes, apple has the upper hand here because they ship one distro on your 
choice of black or white hardware.  Having an extremely small set of 
configurations to target and selling them in large numbers has to be 
easier.  I wonder if a Linux laptop vendor with the same approach would 
get any traction?  From what I've seen of Emperor Linux, they are 
stretched rather thin to be offering the variety that they do and I'm 
sure they don't have nearly the volume of apple.

Think about what it would cost to provide a lifetime of QC'd kernel 
upgrades (e.g. no regression in suspend, X, etc) on every system ever 
sold and what sales volume would be required to support that kind of 
testing.

that whole keyboard thing.  I'm trying to break the esc habit and 
switch to ctrl+C (meanwhile, vim dutifully keeps offering help when I 
forget it's a thinkpad and whack the misplaced F1 key.)  I also sorely 
miss the super and menu keys :-(

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon May 21 07:05:48 2007
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 21 May 2007 07:05:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] deep philosophical question
In-Reply-To: <20070521035441.GS12172@merlot.com>

Kurt,

I've been using a PowerBook G4 for about 28 months now. The 
integration you observed between the hardware and software is, in my 
experience, quite good. I've yet to have a native application give me 
fits.

I haven't had the troubles with *nix apps reported by Quentin, Rogan, 
and Eric. Well, let me put that another way. My first experiences with 
fink were so bad that I almost immediately started using Darwin Ports 
instead. On one host I maintain, the local port database inexpicably 
got corrupted and I ended up having to rebuild all my installed ports. 
Otherwise, Darwin Ports has been good to me. Caveat: I don't use local 
X apps, so I can't speak to their usability.

Another caveat: I'm a sysadmin, not a developer. At work, I typically 
fill my desktops with nothing more than a web browser (I use both 
Safari and Camino) and several terminal windows. I lightly use MS 
Office, Preview, a calendaring application, and some administrative 
utilities. I run a dual-display setup, with my laptop LCD and an 
external monitor running simultaneously. Otherwise, I don't stress my 
system at all.

(At home, the story's a bit different: I use iTunes and GarageBand 
quite extensively. But I'm talking about work now...)

In other words, I tend to use the command-line side of OS X along with 
a web browser, and everything works just fine for me.

That said, it's worth adding a footnote. A couple months ago, I had to 
take the PowerBook in for repairs (dying HD). While it was in the 
shop, I used an older Dell Latitude D800 with Ubuntu. Since I keep my 
most important home-directory config files in a subversion repository, 
I was able to check them out and get up and running in almost no time. 
The whole Mac->Linux conversion took less than an hour. Everything 
just worked. Since I spend most of my time in terminal windows, I 
didn't really notice any difference.

(At home, it'd probably take me *much* longer to find and learn 
suitable replacements for iTunes and GarageBand, but that's a 
different story...)

My two cents.

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> http://www.madboa.com/

Well, for openers, one thing nobody in this thread has mentioned is that 
the overwhelming majority of Rubyists love Macs. And that's mostly 
because their muscle memory is tied into TextMate. Rails folk picked it 
up from them, or maybe it's the other way around. Had you gone to some 
other conference, you probably would have found a different breakdown.

So ... if you're "serious about Ruby and Rails professionally", whatever 
that means, join the crowd and get a Mac. For me, Ruby isn't a 
professional thing yet, and I don't know if I'll ever get around to 
Rails, and I enjoy hacking, etc., etc., etc., so I will stick with 
Gentoo and Windows as needed.

One other note: I'm sure I'll get banned to PLUG-TALK for saying this, 
but there is absolutely nothing wrong in my opinion with paying money to 
buy a quality non-free software product! There's no need for guilt. 
OpenOffice.org won't do what Microsoft Office does. Firefox is no more 
secure than Internet Explorer. And in the Ruby/Rails world, there's 
TextMate and there's "everything else".

What *is* wrong, in my opinion, is paying for non-free junkware, or 
defending and using free junkware. If a piece of software sucks, 
regardless of origin, junk it and buy or download something that doesn't!

What matters in the end is which platform makes you happy.  Linux
users are cut from different cloth than Mac users.  Linux users like
to tinker, while Mac users do not.  If you really want a computer that
you cannot and need not tinker with, try a Mac.  I've worked
side-by-side with Mac users, and I've endured their endless rantings
re: how their little laptops just work right out of the box.  I would
always return fire with how much tinkering I could do on my machine if
I so chose, just to remind them that there is another side to the
coin.  I'd say things like, "Macs are sweet, as long as you like
Aqua."

Carlos Konstanski

From russell at personaltelco.net  Mon May 21 09:28:13 2007
From: russell at personaltelco.net (Russell Senior)
Date: 21 May 2007 09:28:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] tar
In-Reply-To: <727fc2ee0705210910s5ad49f10qc9ca61019d377170@mail.gmail.com>
References: <727fc2ee0705210910s5ad49f10qc9ca61019d377170@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <86abvy9m5e.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "User" == User Iam <vramnum10 at gmail.com> writes:

User> Hi I am having a small tar problem..

User> I need to move some files from my SCO box to my SLED10 <Suse
User> Linux> box..

User> On SCO I do

User> tar cvf /dev/f0 <file to be moved> The disk lite comes on...
User> And I assume it is writing to sucessfully to it.

User> I was thinking I could use tar xvf /dev/fd0 <file to be
User> moved>.tar in a seperate directory to verify it was actually
User> working??  This doesn't work

User> Is there a better way??

Read the Fine Manual, perhaps?

In the first command, you are writing a tarball to a block device
(from context, I assume it's a floppy).  So, to extract it you just
give it the floppy device.  There is no .tar file per se, since there
is no filesystem on the floppy at that point.

But, to just verify that the tar contains the files as expected,
replace the "c" with a "d" (the "diff" option):

  tar dvf /dev/f0 <file to be moved>

If you really want to extract it to a different place:

  cd /somewhere-new
  tar xvf /dev/f0

should unpack whatever files you tar'd in the first command to the new
location.  There is not foo.tar, remember.  No filesystem on the
floppy at that point.

Or better yet, just use rsync and copy the files over the network,
assuming an SCO box has something remotely 21st Century like that.


-- 
Russell Senior, Secretary
russell at personaltelco.net

The article was stating that the displays are faking it, so I don't
think you'd be able to tell from software.  I think to be able to tell
you would need to know the make/model of actual display, which the
article states most MB/MBPs are from a single vendor who doesn't make
8-bit displays except in 20 in. or higher.  The GPU is still running
at 8-bits/color in case you hook up an external display.  I'm not an
expert on this stuff though.

What I gathered though is that most 15 in. and larger laptop displays
are 6-bits/color, so I don't think this is a unique issue to Apple.

From plug_1 at robinson-west.com  Mon May 21 14:15:46 2007
From: plug_1 at robinson-west.com (someone)
Date: Mon, 21 May 2007 14:15:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] deep philosophical question
In-Reply-To: <200705202128.17311.ewilhelm@cpan.org>
References: <20070521035441.GS12172@merlot.com>
	<200705202128.17311.ewilhelm@cpan.org>
Message-ID: <1179782147.1536.50.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

> Possibly running linux on something non-dell would help?  Maybe a mac.
> 
> --Eric

My 7 pound Dell Inspiron 5100 works very well with Fedora Core 5 Linux.
Heck, I even got a working battery life indicator moving from Core 3
to Core 5.  The bigger problem if you standardize on openoffice is that
a document made in the 2.0.2 version isn't compatible with the typical
OO install found on Fedora Core 3.  Oops!  Another problem with Fedora,
which is becoming a growing issue, is short lived repositories.
I think yum is doing more harm than good these days because of how
fast Fedora turns over.  You are almost better off ignoring updates 
and moving one whole release at a time.

Proprietary anything on Linux is going to suck until the producers 
of it are willing to either a) future proof it, or b) support long 
term updates for it.  I have been playing with savannah's 
yealink-module to try and replace a proprietary usb phone driver
for example so that I can move Fedora Core 3 systems to say 
CentOS 5.  I have avoided Ubuntu so far because of the whole 
proprietary drivers thing, but my brother John has adopted it
heavily.

Hibernate is pathetically broken on PC's in general.  I don't
think being a Dell, Toshiba, etcetera has much to do with the
problem.  The people who implement ACPI hardware and write
software, including bios, to work with it must not talk to
each other much.  Apple isn't cloned as far as I can tell,
so there aren't as many apple power management implementations
as there are PC ones.  If PC makers were not afraid
to share their power management designs with the OSS community,
perhaps this wouldn't be such a big problem.

Things that tend to be a problem on laptops are 
incompatible special function keys.  This is easily 
solved by connecting the buttons to the device they 
control directly in a standard way so that you don't 
need to have a special keyboard driver or map.

I have been watching ReactOS, but I am very 
discouraged with the project.  They are getting 
a lot of regressions with each release and making 
inaccurate claims about when new releases will 
come out.  At what point is implementing an NT 
like system that is stable but not 100% compatible 
better than copying something which is badly broken?  
The theory of ReactOS is plug the Windows driver in 
and it will just work.

Freedos is supposed to move to a post 1.0 release.

I found out that I can run Wordperfect 6.0 dos 
using freedos.  It would be nice to find a free
freedos compatible word processor that is open 
office compatible.  Too bad I don't have a 
simple dos based note taking system for what 
someone is telling me on the phone.  A simple
spreadsheet for phone numbers would also be
nice.

A 486 DX2-66 is not the best Linux machine even 
with 20 megs of ram.  Even in tab window manager, 
mozilla 1.1 is not fast enough to access horde 
webmail imp comfortably.

How hard would it be to port mozilla to freedos?

Clearly, the Linux community can improve 
compatibility over time with the diverse hardware 
that exists.  Supporting some hardware sooner 
means proprietary drivers, which IMHO are still a 
huge headache.  An idea I have is to discourage
the writers of proprietary software from burning all
paper copies of their source code and deleting all
digital copies when they are done selling it.

Michael C. Robinson



From ron at Opus1.COM  Mon May 21 13:30:14 2007

Kurt Sussman wrote:
> I spent a few days at RailsConf, and learned a ton. But it was a little
> frustrating watching the Mac users... Macs just work. Sleep, hibernate,
> wifi, Textmate, Quicksilver, it all just works.

...most of the time.

I've used Macs since '84, linux since '98, and DOS/MS Windows and other 
*nix'es thoroughout that time period. Yes, on a Mac, *provided the tools 
are already built*, the tools often just work. ("-39? What the heck is 
-39? aw screw it, I'll just reboot, rebuild my desktop"..... etc).

If the tool doesn't exist yet on a Mac, it's often an SOL situation, or 
a "port it yourself" situation.

> I'm planning to buy a new laptop around the end of the year even though
> my 4 year old Dell runs Ubuntu just fine. Because sometimes the wifi just
> won't hook up, and sleep has never worked under any distro, and the
> display blows out every year like clockwork (warrantees are great!).
> But there's nothing like Textmate on any platform. Except the Mac.

It's a great editor, but speaking as a dev/admin type who has worn quite 
a few hats over the years, I really haven't found an "optimal" single 
platform, or even an optimal single editor. To this day, I find myself 
switching between numerous editors and IDE's in order to quickly 
accomplish my goals, and on some projects, I may find myself using a 
blend of 6 editors and 3 project tools to quickly work on a single 
15,000 line hunk of code.

> So there's the freedom issue; Linux is free and OSX isn't. I like
> freedom, and I'm willing to do my part to keep it, but at what point do
> I just use the best tool for the job and assuage my guilt by working on
> free server apps?

For me, "best tool for the job" is the first priority out of economic 
neccesity. Professionally, I am not paid to be religious about a 
platform, I am paid to deliver results. If I can do something twice as 
fast by using some proprietary hunk of software, I will do so.

> Yes, Macs cost more than the basic Linux-capable PC. But if it saves me
> 30 minutes per day (which is pretty conservative, I think), it will take
> me 20 days of paid work to make up the difference. So is it really more
> expensive?

If you lose tools that you *need* to have, yes. If you do not lose the 
tools, and make up for it in productivity, no.

When a client/cow-orker/manager sends you a flowchart in Visio or Dia 
format, for example, they are not always happy if you reject their 
diagram for religious/platform reasons. In such a case, having a "tool 
capable" platform that can run the needed tools is really the essense of 
the problem.

I suppose this is where the newer X86 macs really excel... they can run 
all of the Win32 tools, the Linux tools, the BSD tools, and the Aqua 
tools, which is something that no other desktop/laptop platform 
currently does.

Of course, if you need a dedicated Solaris tool... or a tool that only 
exists on HP/UX....

> I'm used to Linux, my servers run Linux, it will save space in my brain
> to use only one OS,

I will certainly conceed that using more than one OS can defnitely 
increase the amount of cycles required to learn/maintain those tools, 
but for my workload, that's a tad like saying it's harder for me to 
learn how to use both a hammer *and* a screwdriver *and* an oscilloscope 
*and* a swiss army knife... I don't really have an option.

> I don't like the 'one menubar to rule them all'
> thing, etc. Or are those excuses to keep doing the same sub-optimal
> thing?

Well, it can be frustrating to try using vim commands in emacs, or 
expecting code folding to work the same in quanta, jedit, and 
dreamweaver, but once you have a large set of tools to work with, the 
amount of things you can apply those tools to, and the choice of tools 
available to fix a problem.... well, having multiple toolkits certainly 
expands one's options.

-Bop

In-Reply-To: <20070521042834.GA15512@xanadu.blop.info>

# from Lucas Nussbaum
# on Sunday 20 May 2007 09:28 pm:

>What's the content of /proc/acpi/wakeup ?

Wow!  That's exactly what I needed to know.  Thanks.

  $ cat /proc/acpi/wakeup
  Device  Sleep state     Status
  PCI1       4            disabled
  ...

So, once I do `echo PCI1 > /proc/acpi/wakeup`, it works from S3.

Recapping, this is what I've had to do.  It would have been great to 
have found this under the search "linux wake on lan howto" about 5 days 
ago.

  1.  Bios must be enabled for wol.
  2.  ethtool -s eth0 wol g
  3.  echo PCI1 > /proc/acpi/wakeup
  4.  echo mem > /sys/power/state
  5.  from another machine: `etherwake $mac_address`

Notes:

1.  Maybe the bios doesn't need to be enabled.  I dunno.  This board's 
bios/behavior is very frustrating -- the nic stays lit even if I set 
"onboard lan: disabled" in the bios!  :-/

2.  Just need to ensure that `ethtool eth0` says: "Supports Wake-on: g"

3.  The echo just toggles the value, so the following is more correct.  
Now, I just need to choose the "correct" place to put it in the init 
scripts.
  grep 'PCI1.*enabled' < /proc/acpi/wakeup >/dev/null || \
    echo PCI1  > /proc/acpi/wakeup

4.  I can't use /etc/acpi/sleep.sh on debian etch (at least not with the 
kernel from linux-image-2.6.18-4-686.)  It appears to have something to 
do with ifdown or rmmod (though manual ifdown and/or rmmod and str works 
fine), but I'm not going to dig around in that right now.

Also note, I still cannot wol from suspend-to-disk or poweroff with this 
board.  That *sort of* aligns with the MB docs, which say "S5 is only 
supported with WOL cable" and "onboard lan uses PME not WOL" -- except 
(ugh) putting the nic in legacy mode from the boot agent allows wol 
from cold power off, so hmmph.  In any case, what I really wanted was 
wake from ram and I got it so I'm happy.  Possibly S5 is fixed in 
2.6.21 or something -- if I get around to that I'll let you know.

Thanks to all for the help.

Hopefully google will index this, but it would really help to have some 
recent, easy-to-find documentation regarding the steps required for 
"linux wake-on-lan / driver / acpi / ethtool".  The scyld page appears 
to have been down for some time now and most everything else I found 
was at least a couple years old.

Thanks,
Eric

the additional pain and suffering.

> I want to be able to boot from a CDROM and have the discovery and
> removal of viruses and other critters automated to a high degree. I've
> tried the free Ultimate CD for Windows (or some such similar name) but

Have you tried BartPE?  There's apyware/plugins listed here:
http://www.bootcd.us/BartPE_Plugins_Category/antivirus/

> What should I buy?

Ghost and a big USB2 hard drive.  Set up a bootable thumbdrive, too.
Generally, bad spyware infestations are best handled by backing up the
user's files, scanning them for macro viruses and doing a full OS
reinstall.  You can speed up reinstalls by putting common drivers and
hotfixes on the USB hard drive.

From m0gely at telestream.com  Tue May 22 21:21:34 2007
From: m0gely at telestream.com (m0gely)
Date: Tue, 22 May 2007 21:21:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] It was going so well...
In-Reply-To: <46533778.90002@alcpress.com>
References: <46533778.90002@alcpress.com>
Message-ID: <4653C14E.3020800@telestream.com>

Ed Sawicki wrote:

> For the past few years I've been fortunate not
> to have to support Windows desktops. Now that
> may be changing a bit. I need to be able to
> disinfect a Windows box without having to spend
> any significant amount of time keeping up with
> the goings on in the Windows insecurity world.

This is impossible.  This is where the meat of all the issues you hear 
about happen.  You're going to get to know Windows better than most 
people if you care about the quality of your work in doing this.  As 
others have mentioned, BartPE with an AV plugin is your best bet for 
offline virus cleaning.  You'll want to spend some time adding in many 
network card drivers though so any system you put the disc in will have 
net access to update the virus def's.

Unfortunately ad|spy|malware mostly needs to be done while the syste, is 
live.  There is a Spybot plugin for Bart, but that class of software can 
be more cancerous to a system than a virus causing damage on multiple 
levels.

It might take you a couple days to learn BartPE and put together a good 
disk that you like, but oh the time it will save in the long run...

> What should I buy?

ERD from Sysinternals (now part of MS).  Their tools are invaluable.

If you're able too, suggest that people use Firefox instead of IE.  I 
keep it and the Flash, shockwave and Java plugins on a thumb drive so 
they have the essential features they expect.  Then I run Spyware 
Blaster on the machine which does some preventative measures in IE and 
FF so malware doesn't get in there to begin with.  I like it because it 
doesn't run in the background and eat resources.  Really, that keeps 
people out of trouble for the most part.

-- 
- m0gely


From bwatson1979 at gmail.com  Tue May 22 22:02:19 2007
From: bwatson1979 at gmail.com (Benjamin Watson)
Date: Wed, 23 May 2007 00:02:19 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] It was going so well...
In-Reply-To: <4653C14E.3020800@telestream.com>
References: <46533778.90002@alcpress.com> <4653C14E.3020800@telestream.com>
Message-ID: <334c4450705222202i699ac7d1he00de7c8e9da663b@mail.gmail.com>

If you're managing a plethora of machines, you may want to think about
disk (re)imaging software such as Deep Freeze.

I know the network admins here at school love it, because it keeps all
of the public and laboratory computers very clean.  Essentially, the
computers reboot each night and the hard drive image is restored back
to the state it was previously.  You can create different images to
suite different needs.

The only drawback here is that the user's data is wiped each day, so
they'd need to have some network and/or removable storage.

Ben

Again, Knoppix is very handy for cloning drives and partitions, even
NTFS filesystems.  Newer versions come with ntfsclone, ntfsresize, and
other ntfs tools, as well as the ntfs-3g drivers for writing to NTFS
filesystems.

I wonder if the follow setup would work to simplify administering
Windows boxes:

- 3 partitions (hda1-Windows system, hda2-Windows data, hda3-linux)
- boot loader is grub, but made to be inconspicuous
- hda3 is large enough to hold a minimal linux install and a pristine
compressed image of hda1
- default operation is to boot into Windows
- alternatively, one can boot into Linux to restore the compressed image
into hda1 or scan for viruses on hda2.

Would that work?

From charlie at schluting.com  Wed May 23 11:09:54 2007

 User Iam wrote:
> Hi
>
> Does anyone know what SCO command is like dmesg??
>

dmesg to see the kernel buffer of syslog messages, or for hardware
config information? 'hwconfig' in SCO does the latter, the former is
just wherever syslog is configured to log, iirc.

From raanders at acm.org  Wed May 23 11:06:01 2007
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Wed, 23 May 2007 11:06:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Ubuntu verses Fedora: fuse-sshfs and fstab
Message-ID: <46548289.8060306@acm.org>

Provocative, eh?

Well I'm trying to set up some systems to auto-magically do a sshfs mount.

So far I've found two different ways to put the entry in /etc/fstab. 
Problem is only one example for Fedora and many for Ubuntu.

The Fedora example looks correct(er) in that it looks like other fstab 
entries.  The Ubuntu is _different_.

Fedora:

guest at guest.login.com:data /mnt/guest fuse \ 
uid=1003,gid=100,umask=0,allow_other 0 0

Ubuntu:
sshfs#user at server.domain.com:/starting/path fuse user,allow_other 0 0

The sharp '#' is something I've never seen before except as a comment in 
the fstab file.  (Well one time I had to put one in as part of the 
SMB/CIF share name.)  With the Fedora I'm trying to figure out how the 
mounter knows to use sshfs instead of EncFS or one of the many others.

Any ideas or suggestions.  This will be for Fedora Core 5 & 6 systems.


TIA,
Rod

The place where you will have problems is when viruses are found in user 
mailboxes.  You want to remove the specific virus, not the whole mail 
spool.

The only real problem I have had with ClamAV is that the virus definitions 
do not get updated as fast as other anti-virus products.  (I used to 
download viruses from nasty parts of the net and test them against  ClamAV 
and then F-Secure.  Anything ClamAV missed and F-Secure caught got 
submitted to ClamAV.  I need to start doing that again.)

F-Secure has a Linux product but it is a real pain to purchace.

I had similar issues with an Atheros card  in  one of my machines  about a
year ago that  match yours almost to the t, I was using a PCI card though
and not a built in bit. From the research I did it had to do with the Mad
Wifi drivers, are you using those? You may want to try disabling the wifi
and see if the machine then stays stable.

Bruce Kilpatrick (bakil_win at verizon.net) typed this ...
> >Since I asked the original question, I finally found out how to make
> >KNetworkManager work, and it's as easy as OSX, and so far, just as
> >reliable. 
> --Kurt
> 
> Could you let me in on the secret.  I can connect in Ubuntu but have not 
> figured out what to change in KNetworkManager.

The secret sauce is to delete all entries in /etc/network/interfaces
except the loopback ones. Then add yourself to the 'netdev' group and
log out. Once you do that, KNetMgr will Just Work(tm). 

At least it did for me.

Feel free to email me privately if that doesn't work. 

--Kurt

From creswick at gmail.com  Thu May 24 11:04:27 2007
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Thu, 24 May 2007 11:04:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Solved: Gnome Panel Problem
In-Reply-To: <4655C582.7030107@bctonline.com>

Message-ID: <c834ec80705241104r7e582ba1n19101e55e8a840ab@mail.gmail.com>

On 5/24/07, Jack Hoke <jwhoke at bctonline.com> wrote:
> Thanks for your responses guys. The problem was that I was not getting
> the complete menu when I right-clicked the panel. It suddenly occurred
> to me that I was not seeing 'add to panel' in the menu so I removed
> several items from the panel and then the complete menu, including
> 'Properties', popped up OK.

You were probably seeing the menu for the items on the panel, rather
than the menu for the actual panel.  I think there is a way to get to
the panel properties through one of the Gnome Settings menus, but I
may be wrong. (xfce and kde both make this simpler, fwiw.)

You can also right-click on one of the panel "handles" on the end, or
there is often a 1-px wide strip between buttons on the panel that
will display the actual "panel" menu.  Or it could be a bug in Gnome
(heck, it could be a "feature", for all I know.)

Regardless, keep in mind that there are many, many alternatives to
Gnome, if/when you become frustrated with it -- don't blame the OS for
problems with the desktop manager :)

--Rogan

From aaron at bavariati.org  Thu May 24 11:26:26 2007
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Thu, 24 May 2007 11:26:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] HP & Linux in Financial News
In-Reply-To: <4655A12B.5080206@gmail.com>
References: <46559997.2090603@comcast.net> <4655A12B.5080206@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20070524182626.GP23939@syrinxpc.com>

On Thu, May 24, 2007 at 07:28:59AM -0700, Sean Whitney wrote:
> My company is working with a very large customer as they implement our
> product.  Our customer used this opportunity to select a Linux OS
> distribution.  The leadership wants RH. We recommended debian and the
> customer's sysadmins agreed.  Since HP's supporting debian, they decided
> on debian.  All that was blown when they talked with the EMC about their
> existing SAN.  They only support RH......

Pretty typical.  Vendors want to use the same processes for Linux as for
other OSes.  RH has done a good job of convincing vendors that their
Linux distro is just as monolithic and slow-moving as proprietary OSes.
So vendors can release drivers and SW hand-built for particular RH
versions, write phone-scripts for their tier-1 support drones, and tick
the "Linux Support" checkbox.

My experience is that if (a) a product is a must-have and (b) the vendor
says they support RH, that's what you're gonna be running everywhere.
I've had good experiences getting vendors to help me use their product
on other distros, but people with the power to make decisions about how
to spend money are usually risk-averse.  They also rarely have
experience with what passes for "Linux support", and how useless it
usually is.

And don't get me started on Windows support,
  Aaron

On Thu, 2007-05-24 at 11:35 -0700, Sean Whitney wrote:
> I don't know.  I haven't looked at the SAN offerings lately, I just
> received a call telling me that debian was out because EMC refused to
> support anything linux other than RH.
> 
> 
> Sean

Mondo backup has an easier time with Redhat based distros than
debian and gentoo.  Linux support should mean, works with Linux.
To accomplish that though, you almost need a completely
open spec product.  Why won't big companies maintain
drivers for 2-3 major Linux distributions?  Support Debian,
Redhat (and derivatives), Gentoo, and Ubuntu and you've
covered almost everyone.  Because of Linux Standards Base,
there should only be a few problem areas.

What is wrong with a license that says, "Here is the hardware 
spec free of charge as long as you don't use it to produce 
our product without either a: fairly compensating us or b: 
getting a license from us to produce it?  Obviously, any
part of our designs that are in the public domain can be
produced by you without a license from us to do so.  You
may write software to work with our design under any license
so long as noone else's use of it is negatively impacted."  
If companies would do the above or something close enough,
Linux support, I believe, would get much better.

I'm not a lawyer, so clearly someone can blow holes through
this.  Maybe it's a place to start though ;-)

     Michael C. Robinson

Jim Karlock wrote:

> Try <scroll Lock><Scroll Lock> 1
> and <scroll Lock><Scroll Lock> 2

If this is like my Omniview Pro, then you need to do 01, and 02, not 1 
and 2.  The first digit is for the bank, the second for the channel. 
These KVM's can be cascaded, so it's a two digit entry.

Thanks.

Last night I looked through the network tools available through YaST on
my SuSE 10.1 machine and found Ethereal. I installed it, but haven't
started reading the manual, yet.

I started this morning with the good old fashioned technique of
disconnecting all the cables, and then putting them back one at a time
until the problem showed up again.

First, I tried a crossover cable between my laptop (WinXP) and the
printer (Brother MFC7820N). Didn't work.

Then I tried just the laptop, the router (disconnected from the cable
modem), and the printer. That works.

When I added the link to the basement, the problem returned. In the
basement I have a switch connected to a Thinkpad 390 (Win98SE) and my
newly installed Slackware 11 machine. I disconnected the Slackware
machine and tried again. The problem went away. At least the problem
changed. I need to try again with only the printer, router, and laptop
and watch the LCD on the printer to be sure. But, at least printing
works again with the Slackware machine out of the picture. Getting real
work done has the priority at the moment, so I'll put off watching the
traffic with Ethereal, or maybe wireshark, until tomorrow.

On 5/25/07, Richard C. Steffens <rsteff at comcast.net> wrote:
> Jason Martin wrote:
> > On 5/24/07, Richard C. Steffens <rsteff at comcast.net> wrote:
> >> What tool can I use to watch traffic on my LAN between my XP laptop and
> >> my Brother MFC7820N printer? I'm trying to figure out if there is
> >> something being sent to the printer that is giving it grief.
> >
> > Wireshark (formerly Ethereal).  There is a Windows installer.
> >
> > http://www.wireshark.org/
>
> Thanks.
>
> Last night I looked through the network tools available through YaST on
> my SuSE 10.1 machine and found Ethereal. I installed it, but haven't
> started reading the manual, yet.
>
> I started this morning with the good old fashioned technique of
> disconnecting all the cables, and then putting them back one at a time
> until the problem showed up again.
>
> First, I tried a crossover cable between my laptop (WinXP) and the
> printer (Brother MFC7820N). Didn't work.

This would only work if you had compatible static IP addresses
configured on both the printer and the laptop.  If either is using
DHCP it would not work.

> Then I tried just the laptop, the router (disconnected from the cable
> modem), and the printer. That works.

If your setup is the standard setup, then the router is your DHCP
server, so is required.

> When I added the link to the basement, the problem returned. In the
> basement I have a switch connected to a Thinkpad 390 (Win98SE) and my
> newly installed Slackware 11 machine. I disconnected the Slackware
> machine and tried again. The problem went away. At least the problem
> changed. I need to try again with only the printer, router, and laptop
> and watch the LCD on the printer to be sure. But, at least printing
> works again with the Slackware machine out of the picture. Getting real
> work done has the priority at the moment, so I'll put off watching the
> traffic with Ethereal, or maybe wireshark, until tomorrow.

Check the network configuration on the Slackware machine and see if
you have an address conflict with one of your other devices.  You
shouldn't need Wireshark/Ethereal to do that.

Jason


From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri May 25 11:57:05 2007

Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> When I added the link to the basement, the problem returned. In the
> basement I have a switch connected to a Thinkpad 390 (Win98SE) and my
> newly installed Slackware 11 machine. I disconnected the Slackware
> machine and tried again. The problem went away. At least the problem
> changed. I need to try again with only the printer, router, and laptop
> and watch the LCD on the printer to be sure. But, at least printing
> works again with the Slackware machine out of the picture. Getting real
> work done has the priority at the moment, so I'll put off watching the
> traffic with Ethereal, or maybe wireshark, until tomorrow.
> 

Perhaps this is obvious to you, but if you are trying to sniff network 
traffic between your XP laptop and the printer using a third machine,
you will need to use a hub rather than a switch.  Some switches have a 
port mirroring feature to deal with this, but mirroring isn't 
typically available on consumer level switches.

galen

>>>>> "Galen" == Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> writes:

Galen> Perhaps this is obvious to you, but if you are trying to sniff
Galen> network traffic between your XP laptop and the printer using a
Galen> third machine, you will need to use a hub rather than a switch.
Galen> Some switches have a port mirroring feature to deal with this,
Galen> but mirroring isn't typically available on consumer level
Galen> switches.

One other possibility that just occurred to me would be for the third
machine to have two ethernet ports bridged together.  Insert the
machine in the path between the end-points somewhere,

  brctl addbr br0
  brctl addif br0 eth0
  brctl addif br0 eth1
  dhclient br0

or something, and then run wireshark/ethereal on br0.

From rsteff at comcast.net  Fri May 25 14:44:07 2007
From: rsteff at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Fri, 25 May 2007 14:44:07 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Home Network Hardware Choices
Message-ID: <465758A7.1000801@comcast.net>

I currently have a mix of 10 and 10/100 routers, switches, and hubs.
(Actually, 1 of each, and it's only the hub that is limited to 10 Mb).

I'm considering the best solution for replacing the hub. Simplest would
be a 10/100 hub, but it looks like hubs are too old school anymore.

The next simplest solution is to just get another 10/100 switch to
replace the hub. The question then, is what brands to avoid. The C-net
switch has never given me any trouble, at least none that I know of. The
Netgear Router has also been reliable. ENU has a no-brand 8-port 10/100
switch for $22, and a Trendnet 8-port 10/100 switch for $24. After that,
the speeds go up to 10/100/1000, and the price doubles.

Does anyone have experience with the no-brand from ENU, or the Trendnet?

The topology (50 cent word -- I hope I'm using it correctly!) is:

Cable Modem -> Netgear Router - both on the second floor

Netgear Router (10/100)
	-> 8 port C-net Switch
	-> Hub
	-> Brother MFC7820N Printer
	-> Wife's XP machine

C-net Switch (10/100) - in the basement
	-> n/c
	-> Slackware machine
	-> Thinkpad 390 (Win98)
	-> spare
	-> n/c
	-> n/c
	-> n/c
	-> Up link -> Netgear Router

Hub (10) - sitting on top of the router
	-> n/c
	-> eTower 466 (Win98)
	-> n/c
	-> Home made Athlon 2100 machine (SuSE 10.1)
	-> Thinkpad 600e
	-> spare
	-> Acer Aspire Laptop (Win XP)
	-> (Unavailable)
	-> Up link -> Netgear Router

(The difference between n/c and spare, above, is that n/c really has no
connection while spare has a cable connected at the switch or hub, but
nothing on the other end.)

Thanks for any advice.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens

I was very, very happy with my Linksys EtherFast 4116  (made by cisco, iirc)

http://www.linksys.com/servlet/Satellite?c=L_Product_C2&childpagename=US%2FLayout&cid=1115416900037&pagename=Linksys%2FCommon%2FVisitorWrapper

I used it for about a year, and it's been sitting in an anti-static
bag since.  I've since moved all my servers to a colo and have no use
for it any more, as all my home networking is wifi these days.  It's
fairly compact, but does have brackets to make it fit into a 19" 1U
rack slot.

If anyone is interested in a switch that works great (and wouldn't

This position is located in The Dalles, OR.

We are looking for exceptional System Administrators, at all levels of
experience, to support our growing office and server infrastructure. The ideal
candidate is goal-oriented, has the ability to handle interrupts while fluidly
switching between several projects, and takes a "work smarter, not harder"
approach.

Responsibilities:

* Configure system and network parameters.
* Monitor system stability and performance.
* Help develop tools to monitor and maintain systems.
* Ensure 24x7 systems operation.
* Rapidly scale systems to meet demand.
* Assist with corporate Linux desktop support.
* Write comprehensive documentation.

Requirements:

* BS or MS in Computer Science or equivalent experience.
* Multiple years of Linux or UNIX system administration experience desired,
* but candidates of all levels will be considered.
* Working knowledge of TCP/IP networking.
* Knowledge of webservers, firewalls/security, NIS/NFS, DNS, MTAs.
* Programming/scripting ability (bourne, bash, perl, python, C).
* Excellent verbal and written skills with outstanding customer service.

From mcubed at slashmail.org  Sat May 26 02:55:05 2007
From: mcubed at slashmail.org (Michael M.)

Subject: [PLUG] Emacs/Gnus Tutorials & Workshops?
In-Reply-To: <20070520120919.39c098ed@terry-desktop>
References: <20070520120919.39c098ed@terry-desktop>
Message-ID: <1180173306.12842.17.camel@amdrifter.domain.actdsltmp>

On Sun, 2007-05-20 at 12:09 -0700, Dr. Terry L. Bonner wrote:
> I was wondering if there are, in the metropolitan area, any quick and
> dirty workshops available for text-based newsreader and email clients?
> 
> Forgive what must certainly seem like a noob question.  Those of us
> who came into the Linux community through Mandrake and Ubuntu are,
> from my experience, woefully deficient in cli and text-based
> applications.   


Not an answer to your question (though I suspect it's no, since if there
were such things someone here would know about them), but I was reading
this the other day:

http://www.terminally-incoherent.com/blog/2007/05/21/a-day-without-x/

and it got me thinking I really should try doing without X for a bit,
just for the sake of learning how to use some of these apps.
Personally, I tend to think I won't do it unless I "have to" -- that is,
it's too easy to fall back on comfy, familiar GUI apps when I'm in X.  I
suppose it might be enough to use a terminal-oriented WM like dwm, wmii,
or twin for a while.

There are lots of such articles and discussions out there -- best cli
apps and so forth.  Some I use in a fairly rudimentary way (vim,
midnight commander), some I've used in the past and still use on
occasion (cplay, links), some I've found difficult to get with (slrn),
and some have always seemed too daunting (mutt, emacs).  And there are
numerous others I've long meant to check out, just for the sake of it.

A "Do Linux Without X (Because You Can!)" workshop series would be
interesting.


-- 
Michael M. ++ Portland, OR ++ USA

From plug_1 at robinson-west.com  Sun May 27 01:34:02 2007
From: plug_1 at robinson-west.com (someone)
Date: Sun, 27 May 2007 01:34:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Posting history crisis...
Message-ID: <1180254842.20285.0.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I have been accused of encouraging cyber crime against a
particular individual by what I've posted here on the
plug list.

I've gone by someone plug_0 at robinson-west.com in the past.

One posting that upsets this person asked the question,
"Is there a weakness in the iBook that allows someone to
hack DNS packets easily?"  I asked this to find a way to
plug a possible hole, not to encourage another attack
of his/her laptop.

Another post has come back to me with an accusation that I
ticked off Opus interactive asking if there could be a
renegade dns server inside their network.  An argument has
been pressed that Opus requested a recent subnet change for
the service I go through as a result of my postings here.

Considering that Opus's policy for abuse is termination of
Internet service, I seriously doubt that the subnet change
had anything to do with upsetting my ISP.  I was told
there is a new organizational system and a need to reduce
the spread of static subnet assignments across their IP
space.  I accept this explanation for Opus making the
change it did and I believe it to be the whole truth.

Is there any chance of having email postings of mine that
are likely to feed future paranoid accusations expunged from
the plug archives?  I really care about this person where
removal is probably the easiest way to address the recent
difficulty between us.  A 100+ meg file is an awful lot to
review...  If only I were a perl expert...

I don't know of a single post to this list that could be
legitimately labeled the XYZ instructions to cyber attack
someone.

For those who read this, please refrain from gossiping about
who my critic is.  That will only make matters worse most
likely.  I ask if you feel you know who it is that you
keep the peron's name to yourself and not share it ;-)

  --  Michael C. Robinson

Free exchange of information will sometimes lead to misunderstandings.
It is the misunderstandings that need to be eradicated, not the free
exchange of information.  Being easily offended does not help the
cause of Freedom.  For example, I work in a building with 200 other
people.  One of them happens to be a compulsive cryer.  Does it mean
I'm doing something something wrong if I say "Hi there" and she starts
crying?  No one in my building thinks so.  Just my two cents.

Carlos Konstanski


From plug_1 at robinson-west.com  Sun May 27 10:48:23 2007
From: plug_1 at robinson-west.com (someone)
Date: Sun, 27 May 2007 10:48:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Posting history crisis...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0705270854040.15559@sphinktoo.pippiandcarlos.com>
References: <1180254842.20285.0.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0705270854040.15559@sphinktoo.pippiandcarlos.com>
Message-ID: <1180288103.20285.49.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

> Free exchange of information will sometimes lead to misunderstandings.
> It is the misunderstandings that need to be eradicated, not the free
> exchange of information.  Being easily offended does not help the
> cause of Freedom.  For example, I work in a building with 200 other
> people.  One of them happens to be a compulsive cryer.  Does it mean
> I'm doing something something wrong if I say "Hi there" and she starts
> crying?  No one in my building thinks so.  Just my two cents.
> 
> Carlos Konstanski

This has merit.  

Despite sounding borderline paranoid myself, what of the argument 
people becoming Linux professionals in the future don't want to 
lose business to someone who dislikes what they've posted here?

The Internet is like an odd recorder that doesn't always present
people positively let alone accurately.  In the radio era, I'm 
sure people would forget what thing someone said on it that 
upset them after a fairly short time.  In this age of digital 
backups and data shelf life of 30+ years, the reality is very different.
The problem doesn't lie with the technology, it's a 
purely sociological one.  What is acceptable today, may, because
of the nature of the Net, look terrible to society 30 years from
now and cost you a job.

How many people recorded radio programs in the 30's?

It's easy to argue that I am proposing far too direct a correlation
between making posts to an Internet email list today and being in
political hot water for it down the road.

Calling recorded (amended?) Net activity speech has some potentially 
nasty implications down the road.  Is it speech anymore if you 
won't say it in a changed political climate with possibly different
opinions about the world?  Maybe you get older and wiser?

     --  Michael C. Robinson

Most modern distros want >256M of RAM and a P4 class computer.
Some people are still using ancient distros because their computers
are incapable of running newer versions.  Often, the ancient
distros do not get security upgrades, so the old machines get
hijacked.  I could use some suggested alternatives for these
people.

What are some decent distros with active security updating that 
still provide a decent user experience (static page browser,
pdf, email, word processing) on older machines?

What works with 128M?
What works with  64M?
What works with  32M?

Libretto 70 (133 MHz Pentium MMX, IIRC) with a 1.5 GB hard drive. I'm 
guessing it would run better with Windowmaker. You have to do some 
hacking to get things into it, however -- it won't boot a Debian floppy, 
so I put DOS 5.0 on the first 25 meg of the hard drive and bootstrapped 
install media in that way. I might go back to it when I get some free 
time if I can pick up a new battery for it -- it's a nice little machine.

Keep in mind that sometimes the install requirements may be bigger than 
the actual runtime...  Like all the RedHat based distros using 
Anaconda.  Beep-Beep-Beep.  Thats the sound of all the Python libraries 
being loaded from a dump truck.

If you want to see whats possible, look at OpenWrt (Linux), which runs 
in 4 MB of RAM and 32Mb of flash!   Likewise PFsense/Monowall 
(FreeBSD).   These all are very nice integrated distros, and focused on 
a relatively narrow scope (routing).

Why is the list being archived indefinitely anyways?  

Surely, I'm not the only one concerned about this who has
posted here before.  There's the idea of having useful 
information archived to avoid answering the same questions 
over and over and over again, but doesn't there come a time 
when the archive should be vetted?

If there's an off topic flame thread on this list, is that 
retained for the archive?

I'm surprised that noone else has raised concerns about the 
archiving policies of this list, or do most readers simply 
refrain from posting any questions here at all avoiding the
whole entire problem altogether?

Someone must be harvesting my email addresses.  Even after
changing them, I am getting heavily spammed again.  If an 
email address is in the archive, it is available for the 
taking.  What are you supposed to do, post to the list 
using an address you won't accept replies back to from the
Net?  Talk about hard to do.  I notice that some messages 
from the plug list don't have a source address of
plug at lists.pdxlinux.org.  If there are as many valid source
addresses for plug list as there are subscribers, it would 
be a mess to list them all and keep that list both current
and as small as possible.

Can a Postfix smtp server do limited sender checking for 
specific recipient addresses without limiting all recipient 
addresses that it relays for equally?  

A valid recipient target could be sender restricted via 
white listing.  Maybe I can have a sender testing free 
recipient target drop email that has attachments or 
indecipherable text.  Another thing I want to try is 
gray listing any incoming email where the source address 
is in a dynamically assigned address pool.

I wish there was a DNS RBL or a DNS RHSBL that I can check 
to see if a sender address is in fact from the plug list.
Such a list should have all the current subscribers to
the list (just the ones that are posting to the list).

     Michael C. Robinson

On 5/27/07, someone <plug_1 at robinson-west.com> wrote:
> Why is the list being archived indefinitely anyways?

Because many, many questions come up more than once, and often the
answers are of use to people who are googling, but aren't on the list.
(or heck, people who are on the list.)

> Surely, I'm not the only one concerned about this who has
> posted here before.  There's the idea of having useful
> information archived to avoid answering the same questions
> over and over and over again, but doesn't there come a time
> when the archive should be vetted?

In my opinion, no.  It's probably in the google cache and the way-back
machine (amongst other caches) anyway.  Once something gets on the
'net there is effectively no way to get rid of it.  I don't foresee
that changing any time soon, so in the meantime, we just have to be
civil about it, and apologize when we make mistakes.

> If there's an off topic flame thread on this list, is that
> retained for the archive?

Yep.  It's not like a history text ;)

> I'm surprised that noone else has raised concerns about the
> archiving policies of this list, or do most readers simply
> refrain from posting any questions here at all avoiding the
> whole entire problem altogether?

I think most people just realize that anything you say can come back
to haunt you, so we try not to make asses of ourselves, and if/when we
do, then we're prepared to deal with the consequences.

> Someone must be harvesting my email addresses.  Even after
> changing them, I am getting heavily spammed again.  If an

Regarding spam issues -- I've been using the same email address for
the last 4-5 years and gmail's filters are still doing a very, very
good job of keeping my inbox clear and my spam folder dirty.  As with
the issues regarding internet archiving, spam is something we can't
seem to avoid, so until things change it seems we must live with it.
Thankfully, technology is pretty capable at preventing it from being
to much of a hindrance for many of us.

--Rogan

I was curious about that too, so I checked the rest of the details. As
far as I can tell, it comes with a PCMCIA wireless card as standard
equipment. It doesn't specifically say why, but my guess is that, if it
has a built in wireless chip, it won't work out of the box with Ubuntu.
I didn't check further, as I'm not in the market for a new laptop at
the moment. But if I were, I'd insist on "the rest of the story" before
placing the order. 

Another issue that has been brought up occasionally on the Ubuntu
forums is whether it ships with 64-bit or 32-bit Ubuntu. That' another
question I would ask before getting out the plastic.

they've done is awesome. Even if it is not a perfect first step, it's
still something no other major computer manufacturer has done and Dell
deserves a major pat on the back. More importantly, I hope the sales
figures will give Dell the bottom line support that will entice them to
expand the offerings.

Does having your laptops on the Red Hat Hardware Compatibility List as 
certified count as nothing? IIRC "major computer manufacturers" have 
been doing that with laptops, desktops and servers for years -- even 
before the great Fedora spin-off. And I think you could buy Thinkpads 
with Linux loaded on them for some time, though possibly it was a third 
party and not IBM selling them. I don't think the Dell/Ubuntu counts as 
much of a "first step" or deserving of a "major" pat on the back. It was 
a business decision, and only time will tell whether it was a wise one 
or not.
> More importantly, I hope the sales
> figures will give Dell the bottom line support that will entice them to
> expand the offerings. 
>   
I don't think that's why Dell did the deal with Ubuntu. I think they did 
it to challenge Red Hat, and *that* I think *does* deserve a pat on the 
back, not "just selling computers with Linux on them at the retail 
level". Please do not take my comments as negative towards Red Hat. ;-)

I don't get anywhere near 500 messages per hour, much less 500 
spam messages per hour, but my system ends up accepting for delivery 
only 45% - 50% of the messages sent to it. Here are the stats for the 
last couple weeks:

Totals:
  10501 -- Messages processed
   3634 -- Messages blocked by rule (34.6%)
   1826 -- Messages rejected during scanning (17.4%)
   5041 -- Messages accepted for delivery (48.0%)

Details...

Messages Blocked By Rule:
   3409 -- Known spam IP address (sbl-xbl.spamhaus.org)
    163 -- Invalid recipient or relay
     62 -- Invalid sender domain

Messages Rejected During Scanning (milter-based):
   1793 -- SpamAssassin
     33 -- ClamAV

A hobbyist mail admin can do whatever s/he likes, but IMO any 
professional admin who doesn't scan inbound mail for nastiness is 
pushing the boundary of incompetence.

While my Comcast has been static for the better part of a year now, 
I'll note that I saw some oddities in my Apache logs last night. Take 
a peek at these three entries:

c-24-20-160-119.hsd1.mn.comcast.net - - [27/May/2007:20:07:02 ....]
c-24-20-160-119.hsd1.or.comcast.net - - [27/May/2007:20:07:43 ....]
c-24-20-160-119.hsd1.mn.comcast.net - - [27/May/2007:20:08:52 ....]

See the DNS flip-flop between 'mn' and 'or' in the hostname? Same IP 
address, different names. It's almost like someone at Comcast is using 
the holiday weekend to move a block of IP addresses between Minnesota 
and Oregon -- or maybe someone made a mistake. Perhaps the address 
block you've been assigned is part of the migration/mistake.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon May 28 12:34:31 2007
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon, 28 May 2007 12:34:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Comcast lease problem
In-Reply-To: <20070528114138.6f63f05b@terry-desktop>
References: <20070528123606.GA23438@bejay.com>
	<1180372028.7078.5.camel@kokopelli>
	<alpine.OSX.0.98.0705281115170.2565@orange.madboa.com>
	<20070528114138.6f63f05b@terry-desktop>
Message-ID: <20070528193431.GA11634@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Mon, 2007-05-28 at 05:36 -0700, poor02 at bejay.com wrote:
> I was wondering if anyone else was having this problem. Recently, 
> my ip lease with Comcast is only for an hour, instead of several 
> days, and it won't auto-renew itself. I called tech support, which 
> was useless. Also, the gateway address I keep getting changes,
> from 71.193.182.1 to 71.236.172.1 to 67.160.144.1 to 67.189.90.1.

Everybody is at home for the three day weekend, with you, surfing. 
All the college students are home, trading songs while mom does
their laundry.  Lots of data moving.  I imagine that is causing
Comcast to do all sorts of rearrangements to adapt.

The Comcast dynamic IP is just that.  I once hired a sysadmin to
help set up my firewall, and he hardwired the dynamic IP address in
a bunch of places (DNS, iptables, etc) because "it never changes".
That plagued me for years, until I learned enough to set up the
network addresses correctly.

You can get your DNS at a place like dyndns.org, and run software
that detects IP address changes and resets the dyndns.org URL to
IP mapping in a minute or so.  Moving IP addresses will still
confuse torrents, though, and a lot of mail servers out there won't
talk to a dynamic IP address - too many spammers use them.

If you want a fixed IP address and a server, either pay Comcast for
the privilege, or run a VPN tunnel to an offsite machine with a
fixed IP address.  I do the latter, and I no longer care what IP
address Comcast assigns to me (as long as it does not match the 
IP address range of my internal 192.168... network).

Keith

PS:  the second sysadmin I hired knew better than to rely on a 
dynamic IP, so there are good ones and bad ones.  When you are 
smart enough to tell the difference, you are probably smart
enough to do it yourself, sigh.

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

On 5/27/07, Pete Lancashire <pete at petelancashire.com> wrote:
> I have not been keeping track but there is DSL Damn Small Linux

  I didn't care for DSL.  I found it too specialized for general use.
It appeared to be a toy for it's developers usage.  Porting new apps
to the distro was a real PITA.  Other than that... it seemed to work
well on small memory platforms.  The wireless support for 802.11
PCMCIA cards worked well.

> > Most modern distros want >256M of RAM and a P4 class computer.
> > Some people are still using ancient distros because their computers
> > are incapable of running newer versions.  Often, the ancient
> > distros do not get security upgrades, so the old machines get
> > hijacked.  I could use some suggested alternatives for these
> > people.
> >
> > What are some decent distros with active security updating that
> > still provide a decent user experience (static page browser,
> > pdf, email, word processing) on older machines?
> >
> > What works with 128M?
> > What works with  64M?
> > What works with  32M?

  My plan was to gift an old Dell Inspiron 3500 (233Mhz Pentium, 96M
Mem) to a girlfriend.  She wanted a laptop to take out with her
telescope.  The planetarium programs on Linux are great tools to help
a new hobbyist with their viewing.  I also wanted to get a PCMCIA
802.11 card working so she could check her email using open access
points.

  I tried installing a number of the "small" distros on the Dell over
the winter.  A lot of them did poor hardware detection and wouldn't
install correctly.  A lot of them didn't include the wireless support
and tools I was looking for.  I was unimpressed.

  I tried installing the "lite" option for a couple of full size
distros.  It didn't work very well.  The machine would boot and run,
but would screw themselves into the ground from race conditions in the
GUI.  Gnome and KDE run very poorly in a cycle-starved condition.

I finally ended up installing the Xfce version of Ubuntu, Xubuntu.
http://www.ubuntu.com/products/whatisubuntu/xubuntu

  It's still a bit heavy-weight for a little machine like a Dell 3500,
but it runs OK.  The good software support makes up for the poor
performance.

  The only problem I've had to fix so far is to disable
smooth-scrolling in AlbiWord.  The smooth-scrolling option kills the
application response time on cycle-starved system.  I never did get
the sound to work.  Support for the Dell's old sound chip has
apparently fallen out of the code.

Steve D...

From creswick at gmail.com  Mon May 28 14:52:17 2007
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Mon, 28 May 2007 14:52:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Small distros for older machines
In-Reply-To: <ff01ea180705281427n3fea77c2y43e9423bcf53cef6@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20070527204119.GC7187@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<47031.69.30.70.177.1180300222.squirrel@petelancashire.com>
	<ff01ea180705281427n3fea77c2y43e9423bcf53cef6@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <c834ec80705281452j657a1ba7j8cd192740ded5f6b@mail.gmail.com>

On 5/28/07, Steve D... <blitters at gmail.com> wrote:
>   I tried installing the "lite" option for a couple of full size
> distros.  It didn't work very well.  The machine would boot and run,
> but would screw themselves into the ground from race conditions in the
> GUI.  Gnome and KDE run very poorly in a cycle-starved condition.

It's becoming a little known secret that the desktop manager / window
manager has absolutely nothing to do with the distribution,
particularly with "lite" installs.  It's  really not difficult to
install a lighter window manager.  They work quite well, too.
(blackbox, openbox, afterstep, window maker, and yes, even
Enlightenment, all run much faster than gnome / kde these days.)

> I finally ended up installing the Xfce version of Ubuntu, Xubuntu.
>   It's still a bit heavy-weight for a little machine like a Dell 3500,
> but it runs OK.  The good software support makes up for the poor
> performance.

Make sure everything in the "services" list is disabled, and/or run
through /etc/rcS.d and rcN.d (where N is your default runlevel,
probably 2,3 or 5) and disable everything you aren't using.

Xubuntu-desktop runs something called "gam_server" that (I think?) has
to do with disk monitoring for some indexed search tool.  Occasionally
it will suck up a good 80-90% of my cpu, and it's always sitting there
at 6-10%.  If you find a way to turn that off, I'd suggest doing so.
(and please tell me if you do ;).

"fasterfox" is probably worth looking into too -- it's an optimized
build of firefox for Linux.  I'm going to give it a shot at some
point, and I'll report back.

--Rogan

On Mon, 2007-05-28 at 09:54 -0700, Michael Rasmussen wrote:
> Rogan Creswick wrote:
> > Double indents indicate someone <plug_1 at robinson-west.com> wrote:
> > >Why is the list being archived indefinitely anyways?
> 
> It's the way of the net.  

I see no reason why a system allowing you to indicate, 
"I don't want post X which I submitted to this list archived,"
can't be discussed here.  

A python/perl/php based engine could show you all of your old 
posts and allow you to set an archive preference.  From that, 
a search for other posts quoting one you don't want archived 
can be done so that those posts will get cut as well.  There 
is already censorship from people other than the original 
authors going on if less than everything goes into the archive
in the first place.  IMHO letting the authors of the posts 
submitted for this list censor their own submissions when it 
comes to the archive makes more sense.  No, this does not 
address what is in off list archives.  Thing is, let me be 
clear that I am not proposing anything to address that issue.

> > >Surely, I'm not the only one concerned about this who has
> > >posted here before.  

> Part of knowing that lists (the vast majority of, not just this one) are
> archived indefinitely is coming to a degree of tolerance.  Everyone has 
> embarrassing bits archived out there someplace. It does promote an
> acknowledgement that no one is perfect all the time.

Accomodating someone's wishes is sometimes seen as a sign of 
respect.  The more comfortable people are communicating over
the Net, the more effectively they will use it.  In this age
of rampant identity theft and growing concerns about the Net 
becoming a toxic treatise on everyone who uses it, I see that
the matter of what should be archived and made accessible is 
a growing one.

Civil liberties fanatics scream about having photos of people
taken at the Super Bowl to filter out terrorists, but I guess
if someone doesn't want to be archived here that this isn't
considered a valid privacy concern.

> What problem would that be?  That in the future someone will find out I didn't
> consult the man page and asked a brain dead syntax question?  That my
> knowledge is limited and I know there's lots of someones who know what I need
> to know and will share?  

Must we discriminate against people in public who ask simple and/or
unnecessary questions?

>   Drifting off topic . . .  (rant ahead)

> > Regarding spam issues -- I've been using the same email address for
> > the last 4-5 years 
> 
> Changing email addresses is an ineffective spam stratagey that annoys people
> who try to stay in touch with you. spammers spam non-existant email addresses!
> 
> Finding an email provider, such as Google, or getting adept at implementing
> traps and filters is a necessity in today's world. 
> 
> My system receives about 500 spam an hour (measured since February 10 of this
> year) and on average one or two of those make it to my inbox.  Spamassassin 
> is the primary tool in that filtering.  

I use it too Rogan, but it misses a lot of emails that 
it would be a real challenge to tune it for.  There are
spammers out there that actually use decipherable text
and forego strange formatting.  Spamassassin follows 
the idea of detecting formatting errors and irregularities
and it uses a realtime blackhole list or two, correct?  At
the end of the day, spammers don't have to disseminate 
irregular email getting them past spamassassin untagged.

If it were feasible to go after spam sources and remove the 
economic incentive to put out unsolicited mass email, spam 
would diminish almost entirely.

This discussion aside, I don't know what your problem is 
Rogan that you feel a need to denigrate me and claim 
that you are ready to rant and rave.

     Michael C. Robinson

From bakil_win at verizon.net  Mon May 28 16:25:03 2007
From: bakil_win at verizon.net (Bruce KIlpatrick)
Date: Mon, 28 May 2007 16:25:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Feisty freeze-ups solved
Message-ID: <465B64CF.7030409@verizon.net>

I recently posted about Feisty-freezeups on my Toshiba laptop.  Drew 
thought the problem sounded very like one he had with the Wifi drivers 
for an Atheros card he had.

The problem turned out to be one related to the boot up error I was 
getting and couldn't remember when I posted to the list.  The error was 
*"MP*-*BIOS bug*: *8254* timer not connected to IO-APIC".

Adding noapic to the boot options took care of the problem.  I should 
have noted the obvious error before I jumped to conclusions.

Thanks for the help.

Bruce

I'm fairly certain there was a degree of sarcasm to Michael
Rasmussen's comments above.     How his comment could relate to
discrimination is a bit of a mystery to me though.

> > My system receives about 500 spam an hour (measured since February 10 of this
> > year) and on average one or two of those make it to my inbox.  Spamassassin
> > is the primary tool in that filtering.
