<snip>

> This discussion aside, I don't know what your problem is
> Rogan that you feel a need to denigrate me and claim
> that you are ready to rant and rave.

Unfortunately, my name ended up at the top of Michael Rasmussen's
message, which is what you were replying to. (Nothing I wrote was
actually in that message. Oh well, it happens, and the fact that it's
archived in public doesn't really bother me that much.)

This does demonstrate one of the reason's I'm not that worried about
an email archive.  Things get messed up *all the time*, and we end up
mis-attributed frequently.  Email is just like that.  If anyone ever
tries to sue me for something Michael Rasmussen said above, then we
can dig around and find all my original messages on this thread, and
prove that no, I didn't say these things (as a side note, I do agree
with most of his points, I'm just using this as an example.).  That's
the other side of the coin -- if everything is archived you can almost
always find out the truth, and that is something I feel very strongly
about.

It is nice to cut people a bit of slack on-line though, and read
things very carefully, lest you (and by "you" I mean anyone) say
something that you will come to regret.

--Rogan

Quoting "Kenneth B. Hill" <ken at scottshill.com>:

> My Gateway laptop ships with 64-bit. It runs Ubuntu Edgy (I think
> this is the current version just fine); however, I had to install the
> i386 version of Ubuntu last year because of recommendations to not
> use the 64-bit version of Ubuntu at that time. I've been using an

> works fine. Yes, the laptop uses a PCMCIA wireless card that is built
> into the board. I think my experience is just another example of the

There is no "lack of hardware drivers for the numerous Linux distros". What
there is a lack of is Linux drivers that will satisfy both the needs of
corporations for profits and the needs of the "open source community" for
freedom of software. So the free as in speech drivers have limits in their
capabilities, and the non-free ones have limits in the way you can legally use
them. For example, I'm perfectly happy with the non-free-speech "nvidia"
drivers on my new machine, because I get twice as many frames per second with
them. If that pisses off Eric Raymond or Richard Stallman, well, too bad. :)

Quoting Rogan Creswick <creswick at gmail.com>:

> It's becoming a little known secret that the desktop manager / window
> manager has absolutely nothing to do with the distribution,
> particularly with "lite" installs.  It's  really not difficult to
> install a lighter window manager.  They work quite well, too.
> (blackbox, openbox, afterstep, window maker, and yes, even
> Enlightenment, all run much faster than gnome / kde these days.)

I buzzed through all of the desktops/window managers at one point before
settling on Windowmaker. I had trouble with the fonts on some of the really
light ones, like blackbox, fluxbox and IceWM -- they were just too small. There
may have been some way of getting bigger ones, but I couldn't find it.

I could never figure out how to work Afterstep -- it did weird things that I
couldn't understand. Enlightenment was interesting, but I found myself spending
a lot of time messing with the settings. XFCE 4.2 was acceptable, but 4.4 was
almost as big as Gnome. So I ended up with Windowmaker, and that's what I run
today. I think Enlightenment was a close #2 -- if you want or need 128
desktops, that's the way to go. :)

I think KDE is probably a lost cause, but I still think you can lighten Gnome up
to the point where it's competitive with XFCE and possibly even Enlightenment
and Windowmaker.

> "fasterfox" is probably worth looking into too -- it's an optimized
> build of firefox for Linux.  I'm going to give it a shot at some
> point, and I'll report back.

I haven't tried fasterfox, but so far I've had pretty good luck with Seamonkey.
It won't do RSS feeds, but other than that, it does everything Firefox and
Thunderbird do as far as I can tell. "Dillo" is a really light browser, but
there are lots of sites that do stuff "dillo" can't handle.

znmeb at cesmail.net wrote: Quoting "Kenneth B. Hill" :

> My Gateway laptop ships with 64-bit. It runs Ubuntu Edgy (I think

There is no "lack of hardware drivers for the numerous Linux distros". What
there is a lack of is Linux drivers that will satisfy both the needs of
corporations for profits and the needs of the "open source community" for
freedom of software. So the free as in speech drivers have limits in their
capabilities, and the non-free ones have limits in the way you can legally use
them. For example, I'm perfectly happy with the non-free-speech "nvidia"
drivers on my new machine, because I get twice as many frames per second with
them. If that pisses off Eric Raymond or Richard Stallman, well, too bad. :)

On May 28, 2007, at 4:05 PM, someone wrote:
> On Mon, 2007-05-28 at 09:54 -0700, Michael Rasmussen wrote:

>> It's the way of the net.
> I see no reason why a system allowing you to indicate,
> "I don't want post X which I submitted to this list archived,"
> can't be discussed here.

So, Scientologists (or whoever) could, say, redact everything posted  
to a list they didn't like, by impersonating users?

> A python/perl/php based engine could show you all of your old
> posts and allow you to set an archive preference.  From that,
> a search for other posts quoting one you don't want archived
> can be done so that those posts will get cut as well.

So, not only censoring *your* own individual words, but *also* the  
words of others? I'm pretty sure that won't fly. Reality is not  
something people will happily allow others to re-write.

Personally knowing a few people who participated in the Froistad  
matter (to save you some googling, he confessed in an online email  
listserv to intentionally murdering his own 5 year old daughter,  
years after it was thought to be an accident), I can say with some  
certainty (after much discussion with them) that once a cat is out of  
the bag, there's no getting rid of it. Once somebody has hit send,  
and "published" their message, they might as well have printed it in  
a thousand copies, and nailed it to telephone polls, mailed a copy to  
the library of congress, and hand-delivered a copy to their mother.

Have an editorial: <http://psychcentral.com/froistad.htm>

>>>> Surely, I'm not the only one concerned about this who has
>>>> posted here before.
>> Part of knowing that lists (the vast majority of, not just this  
>> one) are
>> archived indefinitely is coming to a degree of tolerance.   
>> Everyone has
>> embarrassing bits archived out there someplace. It does promote an
>> acknowledgement that no one is perfect all the time.
> Accomodating someone's wishes is sometimes seen as a sign of
> respect.

Froistad: Can you remove my online murder confession?
List Manager: uhm, no. You published it to thousands of hard drives  
all over the world. Any of the places you chose to publish to, by  
posting, can make their personal archives public at any time..... See  
you in 25-30 years.

> The more comfortable people are communicating over
> the Net, the more effectively they will use it.  In this age
> of rampant identity theft and growing concerns about the Net
> becoming a toxic treatise on everyone who uses it, I see that
> the matter of what should be archived and made accessible is
> a growing one.

If there is rampant identity theft, there can also be rampant false  
requests of removal (in your proposed scheme). So, an enemy could  
request all posts of yours be removed, except for the joke you made  
involving sheep and cliffs.

As far as private communications systems, that are *not* archived,  
those certainly do exist (in a few places), but all parties have to  
agree to not capture or store that information. When you're deep  
inside certain industries (such as working with TOP SECRET or Q  
information) releasing that data is enforceable by 10 years of jail,  
per infraction.

Everything else, by default, is slowly getting archived (in the US)  
for SARBOX reasons, liability reasons, and system restoration reasons.

> Civil liberties fanatics scream about having photos of people
> taken at the Super Bowl to filter out terrorists, but I guess
> if someone doesn't want to be archived here that this isn't
> considered a valid privacy concern.

If you don't want to be archived, you need to have a pre-arranged  
agreement with all parties involved that they will not archive....

It's not that far from being taped at the super-bowl. If you don't  
want to have your actions recorded by anybody with a camera there,  
don't go there.

If you want to be on an email list without anybody archiving the  
list, you have to be on a list where all parties agree to not  
archive, and there is some form of enforcement/penalty for doing so.

>> What problem would that be?  That in the future someone will find  
>> out I didn't
>> consult the man page and asked a brain dead syntax question?  That my
>> knowledge is limited and I know there's lots of someones who know  
>> what I need
>> to know and will share?
> Must we discriminate against people in public who ask simple and/or
> unnecessary questions?

Yes.

If your post history is 95% asking questions, and 5% answering  
questions, people will know ahead of time that you are more  
interested in having others do your work than doing it yourself and  
helping others. It's discrimination against people who are unhelpful  
to the community, against "vampires" who want to suck from F/OSS  
rather than pull their own weight.

There is an actual solution to this, of course.

Spend more time helping others, as compared to asking others to help  
you.

If somebody googles you, and sees 300 helpful responses, and one  
silly question, they will know that you will be capable of helping  
them. If they see 300 posts about breaking into machines, and only  
one post about preventing breakins, they will again have an accurate  
picture.

-Bop

> I was curious about that too, so I checked the rest of the details. As
> far as I can tell, it comes with a PCMCIA wireless card as standard

Where did you see a PCMCIA card option?  The wireless option I clicked
through to was an Intel PRO/Wireless 3945a/g mini-PCI card.  That's
the same card thats in all those Centrino laptops out there that work
just fine with Linux.

Be careful equating "built-in" to "doesn't work with Linux".  The
make/model of the wireless controller matters more than whether it is
permanently attached to the system or not.

From creswick at gmail.com  Tue May 29 10:32:44 2007
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue, 29 May 2007 10:32:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] using VM Ware for "real" work -- has any one had success
	with this?
Message-ID: <c834ec80705291032t5a7267fcjc0f29e5074e09c6e@mail.gmail.com>

I'm trying to migrate to Linux at work, but there are a few
"must-have" apps that I'm having issues with:

    * Word (OpenOffice doesn't cut it.  It can't read/write .doc files
with high enough reliability.)
    * Visual Studio
    * Visio

The reason these are "must-have" apps is that I have to be able to
interact with other people who use them -- I could (and do) accomplish
the same results with entirely OSS tools, but I'm not aware of
anything that will say, read and write visio files, and let me create
XP-themed UI mockups.

I'm considering getting Crossover Office to run Word and Visio, and
I'm working on linux ports of our software, so VS may not be a lasting
issue.  In the meantime though, I still need to use these apps, so
I've installed vmware player and made a 35gig image of my old XP pro
install.  I've done this sort of thing in the past with Win2k on a
dual-proc (2x 1ghz T-bird) machine, but now I'm on a single-core
Athlon 64 (running 32-bit Feisty) and I'm having horrible performance
problems.

The issues seem to be tied to disk thrashing -- the drive is
constantly active while VM Ware is running, and the XFCE performance
monitor reports 100% processor activity (although Top shows minimum
levels of activity ~12%).  Native Linux apps run just fine while VM
Ware is going, but anything in the virtual machine is extremely slow.

I have installed the vmware tools, and I'm using VMware Player, as
opposed to VMWare workstation, which I was using before with success.
I'd give VMWare Workstation another try, but I've seen indications
that vmware player works just fine for some people on line.  Could the
size of the image be the problem? (35 gigs -- *much* larger than any
virtual machine I've used in the past.)

Any suggestions / ideas about VM Ware, or interoperating with the
windows apps above would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks,
Rogan

laptop with me today.)

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue May 29 13:06:00 2007
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue, 29 May 2007 13:06:00 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] using VM Ware for "real" work -- has any one had success
	with this?
In-Reply-To: <c834ec80705291032t5a7267fcjc0f29e5074e09c6e@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c834ec80705291032t5a7267fcjc0f29e5074e09c6e@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20070529200600.GA26351@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Tue, May 29, 2007 at 10:32:44AM -0700, Rogan Creswick wrote:
...
> The issues seem to be tied to disk thrashing -- the drive is
> constantly active while VM Ware is running, and the XFCE performance
> monitor reports 100% processor activity (although Top shows minimum
> levels of activity ~12%).  Native Linux apps run just fine while VM
> Ware is going, but anything in the virtual machine is extremely slow.

Others have suggested increasing the memory, a good idea.  You
should also use a shipping version of VMware, not a beta version. 
The beta versions of VMware are loaded up with debug stuff, which
slows it *way* down.

The currently available version of VMware Player 2 is no longer
beta.  There are sites such as easyvmx.com and others where you
can use an online fill-in form to create .vmx files, so you don't
need Workstation or Server for this task.

BTW, you should also set up host-based networking (with NAT to
get out to the net) and an internal samba server to store most
of your Windoze files.  This permits you to work with those files
from both operating systems, and use the faster and more robust
Linux file systems to access them.  Samba adds some overhead,
slowing you down, but it improves interoperability between your
few Windoze apps and your many Linux apps, and gives VMWare and
Windoze less disk management to do.  Imagine how slow the "swap
virtual guest memory" to "virtual page file" on a "virtual disk"
stored as a giant Linux file must be.  I don't know if a page
file accessed through Samba would be slower or faster, but it
would be an interesting experiment to try.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

What I meant to say is that my Gateway notebook as internal wireless  
(a.k.a. builtin); meaning I don't need to purchase a wireless NIC to  
place in the PCI slot in the notebook. At the time I was trying to  
troubleshoot this, there was much information on the Ubuntu Forum,  
but it required more of my time than I wanted to spend on it; I found  
it a better use of my time to use a Linksys Wireless card and insert  
it into the notebook's PCI slot. I also tried some other Linux  
distros (such as Mandrake) to see if it would automatically detect  
the internal wireless, and it didn't.

I think any Linux distro can increase their user base if they can get  
their "standard" installation to automatically detect the internal  
wireless like it can with the ethernet NIC. I really like using my  
Ubuntu Linux laptop, but sometimes the small things that don't work  
just "get to me".

When I find some time to troubleshoot this some more, I will explore  
help from this group.

> "fasterfox" is probably worth looking into too -- it's an optimized
> > build of firefox for Linux.  I'm going to give it a shot at some
> > point, and I'll report back.
>
> I haven't tried fasterfox, but so far I've had pretty good luck with
> Seamonkey.
> It won't do RSS feeds, but other than that, it does everything Firefox and
> Thunderbird do as far as I can tell. "Dillo" is a really light browser,
> but
> there are lots of sites that do stuff "dillo" can't handle.


Actually FasterFox is a plug-in extension to regular Firefox, and SwiftFox
is a specifically compiled optimized Linux version of Firefox with several
speed optimizations and other tricks.  I run it but haven't measured any
huge noticeable difference.  It is "fast" but I can't tell you exactly how
much faster it is than regular Firefox.

Thus the fasterfox plug-in will work with Firefox on Linux, Mac, and
Windohs.  Swiftfox is only for Linux on Intel/AMD.

Fasterfox:
http://fasterfox.mozdev.org/

Swiftfox:
http://getswiftfox.com/

NB that some network admins would consider the pre-fetching that these do to
be "uncool" from a network load standpoint (so I've heard anyway).

At any rate if you are looking for lean 'n' mean, any Firefox should be a
bit better than the full SeaMonkey suite.  The real small browsers like
Dillo would work even better, for simple pages.  For complex stuff you have
to find a happy middle I suppose.

> but

Actually FasterFox is a plug-in extension to regular Firefox, and SwiftFox
is a specifically compiled optimized Linux version of Firefox with several
speed optimizations and other tricks.  I run it but haven't measured any
huge noticeable difference.  It is "fast" but I can't tell you exactly how
much faster it is than regular Firefox.

Thus the fasterfox plug-in will work with Firefox on Linux, Mac, and
Windohs.  Swiftfox is only for Linux on Intel/AMD.

Fasterfox:
http://fasterfox.mozdev.org/

Swiftfox:
http://getswiftfox.com/

NB that some network admins would consider the pre-fetching that these do to
be "uncool" from a network load standpoint (so I've heard anyway).

At any rate if you are looking for lean 'n' mean, any Firefox should be a
bit better than the full SeaMonkey suite.  The real small browsers like
Dillo would work even better, for simple pages.  For complex stuff you have
to find a happy middle I suppose.

> windows apps above would be greatly appreciated!
>
> Thanks,
> Rogan
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>
1. If your main requirement is to communicate with Windows users, you 
probably ought to be running it the other way around -- a Windows host 
and a Linux guest.
2. VMware ain't magic. Every byte of memory the host and guest uses has 
to really be in the machine. Every CPU cycle the host and guest execute 
must get executed. And every byte that gets written to disk, permanently 
or temporarily, has to get written to disk. In other words, if you're 
trying to jam two workloads into one machine with VMware, you're gonna 
be slow.
3. I haven't done much testing with VMware player -- schlepping around 
even 4 GB (compressed!!!) disk images is a non-starter. It takes time to 
burn them to a DVD, time to copy them from machine A to machine B, etc. 
As to free server versus paid-for workstation, I don't have a lot of 
experience, but Workstation has a lot more flexibility than the free server.

In short, do your homework, don't expect miracles, you get what you pay 
for, your mileage may vary, offer void where prohibited by law, and 
lions bite. ;)

> 1. If your main requirement is to communicate with Windows users, you
> probably ought to be running it the other way around -- a Windows host

My main requirement is a workstation that I can bear to work with on a
daily basis, and do so without loosing productivity :)  Most of what I
do is code (in java, c#, haskell, lisp or perl) and crunch data
generated by the tools created in the coding phase :).  Both these
steps are infinitely easier for me in a linux environment, and often
these things become very processor intensive, so running that
environment as a guest is sub-optimal.

> 2. VMware ain't magic. Every byte of memory the host and guest uses has
> to really be in the machine. Every CPU cycle the host and guest execute
> must get executed. And every byte that gets written to disk, permanently
> or temporarily, has to get written to disk. In other words, if you're
> trying to jam two workloads into one machine with VMware, you're gonna
> be slow.

After turning *everything* down re: visual effects (but keeping the
resolution to 1280x1024 or so), and disabling all the resident
processes that were running, it's working quite well.  I can use word
and visio (independantly, haven't tried them together) as quickly as I
can when running XP natively.

In some respects this setup is actually *faster*.  Because I do *all*
of the "dangerous" things in the linux host (email, browse, access
network shares, run programs... etc.) I'm comfortable turning off some
things that I would be unable to do if running XP as a host.  The
antivirus doesn't need to scan daily, for example, and I don't need an
XP-based firewall.  Those two things alone have freed up many, many
resources.

Thanks for all the help!

--Rogan

> You are right and wrong. Linux 32 bit drivers are not as compatible as Windows 32 bit drivers because there are more of them. However when you can't install Windows VISTA 64 bit on your laptop because if you did the drivers probably would not be available and you would not even be able to connect to the internet or play sounds. You may not even get your video to work resulting in a Blue Screen. Now those 32 bit drivers for Linux we were talking about well they work just fine for Linux 64 bit. Why? Because they are open source and can just be recompiled. 64 bit runs way faster on a 64 or 128 bit computer. Sure they should run faster but because they only have Windows 32 bit on them they run as slow as the computers 3 years ago. Most people don't understand this. You on the other hand have used both Ubuntu 64 bit and 32 bit so you know full well what runs faster.

I installed Arch64 on my desktop for about two weeks.  The only thing
that seemed slightly faster (and I do mean "slightly," not "way faster")
than on my 32-bit installation of same was encoding audio to flac and
ogg.  My guess is that video encoding would have been slightly faster,
too, but I don't do much of that.  OTOH, the ripping process (from audio
CDs) was no faster, and that's what takes the most time anyway.
Everything else that I use my computer for was not perceptibly faster.
I'm sure there is plenty of usage that benefits from a 64-bit
environment on 64-bit hardware, but I don't have a need for it.  For
day-to-day "(stereo)-typical home usage" stuff, I can't see any
advantage of using a 64-bit installation, and plenty of pain that goes
with the lack of gain (some multimedia codecs, flash and other
proprietary bits-and-pieces that aren't available in 64-bit Linux or are
difficult to set-up).  It's not worth it, IMO.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed May 30 07:56:58 2007
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 30 May 2007 07:56:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] selinux and permissions
In-Reply-To: <20070530055328.GA31049@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20070530055328.GA31049@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <alpine.OSX.0.98.0705300749280.21502@arrowhead.galois.com>

On Tue, 29 May 2007, Keith Lofstrom wrote:

> Any selinux experts here?

Practicioner, maybe. Expert, hah!

> I am working with a Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 clone, which comes 
> with selinux set to "enforced" mode by default.  I installed liblzo2 
> to work with openvpn.  When I ran it (as root), I got an error 
> message (linewraps added by me):
>
> Starting openvpn: /usr/sbin/openvpn: error while loading shared \
> libraries: liblzo2.so.2: cannot enable executable stack as shared \
> object requires: Permission denied

Right. Dan's suggestion to grep for avc in /var/log/messages won't 
work in RHEL 5 and clones. You'll need to find the right bits in 
/var/log/audit/audit.log, but before you do that...

First, look at liblzo2.* using "ls -Z". The SELinux context should be

   system_u:object_r:lib_t

The last bit ("lib_t") is probably the most important. If your library 
doesn't have that context, use chcon to reset it:

   sudo chcon -t lib_t /path/to/liblzo2.*

Try openvpn again (under an enforcing policy) and see if that helps. 
If not, check back in and I'll post something about altering SELinux 
policies in RHEL 5.

Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> http://www.madboa.com/

From KEN at scottshill.com  Wed May 30 11:27:32 2007
From: KEN at scottshill.com (Kenneth B. Hill)
Date: Wed, 30 May 2007 11:27:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] LAMP Platform Updating Problems
Message-ID: <C94E0348-837D-4C4D-A70B-0B4B3D169004@scottshill.com>

I have a been leading a development project of a database app that is  
built on a LAMP-variant platform (it uses Gentoo Linux, Apache,  
PostgreSQL AND PHP) along with some CPAN perl modules and MapServer.  
We seem to have problems with updates to the individual LAMP tools  
not working with the other LAMP tools. For example, if we update  
Apache with a security update, then we experience with features in  
the app not working in a perl mod or PHP etc.

I recently got back from a business trip, and I sat next to someone  
on the airplane that does LAMP database application development. I  
shared with him this experience, and he agreed with me that this is  
an underlying problem with developing in a LAMP environment/platform.  
This results in increasing our labor/time costs in maintaining the  
infrastructure of the application. I would like to hear other  
experiences with this issue - if any.

-Ken

From jenred at gmail.com  Wed May 30 13:58:26 2007
From: jenred at gmail.com (Jennifer Redman)
Date: Wed, 30 May 2007 13:58:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] LAMP Platform Updating Problems
In-Reply-To: <C94E0348-837D-4C4D-A70B-0B4B3D169004@scottshill.com>
References: <C94E0348-837D-4C4D-A70B-0B4B3D169004@scottshill.com>
Message-ID: <93f118f0705301358u3dd5bdf4w531b5dc12789f672@mail.gmail.com>

Hi Ken,

This can be one of the frustrating aspects of using Open Source software in
production.  Disparate development teams don't have to make sure everything
works with everything (which would be impossible) and sometimes upgrades
break seemingly unrelated pieces of software.

However, some distros  come pretty close to solving this issue -- by
offering "stable"  package collections.  Everything is tested and works
together.  Ubuntu, Debian, RHEL, Centos, and Suse follow this practice.  You
lose some of the flexibility of running Gentoo -- but at least applications
"should" continue to work together without feature loss, when recommended
updates are rolled out.

Another option is to make sure you test all upgrades including patches on a
staging environment first -- and closely review whether or not you "really"
need the patch and at the same time review all the potential dependencies,
and then fix all the problems before rolling to production -- can take a lot
of time though.

Jen

From aaron at bavariati.org  Wed May 30 14:29:58 2007
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Wed, 30 May 2007 14:29:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] LAMP Platform Updating Problems
In-Reply-To: <C94E0348-837D-4C4D-A70B-0B4B3D169004@scottshill.com>
References: <C94E0348-837D-4C4D-A70B-0B4B3D169004@scottshill.com>
Message-ID: <20070530212958.GA19365@syrinxpc.com>

On Wed, May 30, 2007 at 11:27:32AM -0700, Kenneth B. Hill wrote:
> We seem to have problems with updates to the individual LAMP tools  
> not working with the other LAMP tools. For example, if we update  
> Apache with a security update, then we experience with features in  
> the app not working in a perl mod or PHP etc.

As a sysadmin with a decent amount of LAMP and dependency-hell behind
me, I can only say that Jennifer's already covered what I would say,
and in much nicer words to boot.

But to reiterate: 
1. Be careful and consistent where you get stuff; mixing CPAN downloads
with distribution-packaged Perl modules is asking for trouble.
2. Be careful what and when you upgrade, and plan for breakage.
3. Use a separate test server.

If you want to go the grumpy-professional-sysadmin route:
4. Document things well enough that you can rebuild your
server/environment from an OS install CD and your PHP source.
5. Get a spare box, set aside a couple days and actually DO #4.
6. Try migrating the app to Debian or Centos.
7. Don't let devs have root access.

From jenred at gmail.com  Wed May 30 16:32:45 2007
From: jenred at gmail.com (Jennifer Redman)
Date: Wed, 30 May 2007 16:32:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] LAMP Platform Updating Problems
In-Reply-To: <76C385FF-4886-45B3-88C4-1999AB308F21@scottshill.com>
References: <C94E0348-837D-4C4D-A70B-0B4B3D169004@scottshill.com>
	<20070530212958.GA19365@syrinxpc.com>
	<76C385FF-4886-45B3-88C4-1999AB308F21@scottshill.com>
Message-ID: <93f118f0705301632le36da93ha4522d07633ffab2@mail.gmail.com>

Although my name is not Aaron -- here's my take on selecting a Linux Distro:

* Make sure the distros stable version supports the software particularly
the version you need.  Talk to the entire development team AND the sysadmins
to make sure you aren't overlooking any dependencies.

* Do a little research into the package management software to figure out
what best suits your environment.  Apt vs Yum vs Up2date etc.

* Look at frequency of updates and make sure they jive with your development
cycles and operations' expectations.

* Check out frequency of security updates and "new" vulnerabilities

Essentially, you need to do a requirements assessment and then proceed.
Moving to a new distribution of Linux will have ramifications -- especially
if you and the Dev team/ SysAdmins are used to gentoo.

Personally, I don't really like the super-automated package managers, but
that's because I'm highly paranoid about even "tested" updates breaking
things.  Thus, I  still believe it's best to roll updates to a testing
server first if you are updating a production environment.

That being said -- I've come around to liking life the Debian/Ubuntu way --
makes for less configuration headaches.  I don't really like the package
management software for CentOS/RHEL, and  Redhat "seems" to be slower in
rolling out new application updates.

It was hard for me to stop compiling software and to move to using packages
(I'm going to take another look at Slackware (used way-back in the late
90's),  I like the idea of a super-clean install and good software version
management.), but I definitely think there is less pain involved if you are
running a production website.  Particularly, if you are managing a large
number of systems.

I would imagine that as gentoo users -- you and the rest of the team may
find this a little painful at first as well.

Strongly suggest sitting down and doing a requirements assessment before
deciding on a new distribution.

Jen

> running a production website.  Particularly, if you are managing a large
> number of systems.

Jen,

   There's slapt-get and swaret. I've used only the first, and then only for
a particular purpose (installing the Freerock Gnome so I could run Gnucash).
Slapt-get manages dependencies; I've no idea about swaret. Many of the
SlackBuild scripts (they build Slackware-style packages totally compatible
with the distributed packages) include a list of dependencies.

From qhartman at gmail.com  Wed May 30 16:56:25 2007
From: qhartman at gmail.com (Quentin Hartman)
Date: Wed, 30 May 2007 16:56:25 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] using VM Ware for "real" work -- has any one had success
	with this?
In-Reply-To: <c834ec80705292027q23857580n467d19d6f0ff7ad2@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c834ec80705291032t5a7267fcjc0f29e5074e09c6e@mail.gmail.com>
	<465CD561.1080503@cesmail.net>
	<c834ec80705292027q23857580n467d19d6f0ff7ad2@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <8975a95f0705301656y564ceb47iaa6803c5590e2565@mail.gmail.com>

I use vmware (workstation and server) everyday to do "real" production
tasks. As do a number of other people at my company. I've just skimmed this
thread, so please forgive me if I mention something someone already has. My
most heavily loaded host server is a dual proc 2.4G Xeon machine with 4GB of
RAM. It is running 7 Windows 2003 vm VM's, and two Windows XP VMs. Some of
my co workers run Visual Studio all day in vmware...

At any rate.

Rogan RE performance / disk thrashing - If you only 1GB of RAM in your host
machine and the VM wants 768, try _reducing_ the amount of memory allocated
to the virtual machine. It's likely that the disk thrashing is being caused
by the hosts needs, not the guests needs. start at 320 and go up from there.
My rule of thumb for desktop usage patterns is to leave 512mb of RAM for
host overhead, 256mb on servers for host overhead. Realistically, you need
more RAM in that machine to get good performance out of both the VM running
XP and apps on the host. It is also _really_ useful to have multiple procs /
cores to work with. If your current machine is uniprocessor, upgrading that
will give you a HUGE performance boost.

-- 
-Regards-

-Quentin Hartman-

On Wed, May 30, 2007 at 03:24:26PM -0700, Kenneth B. Hill wrote:
> Why do you recommend Debian or CentOS over Gentoo? What are your  
> thoughts about Ubuntu?

My apologies for not speaking clearly.  I meant to say, try migrating
your current setup to some other distro as a practice drill.  

I'll admit that I strongly prefer Debian or Ubuntu for my own setups,
because of the stability, long-term support and incredible selection of
packages.  CentOS is nice to use when I think the client might decide to
migrate to Redhat because of vendor-support issues.

With either one, I can usually install a distribution package for any
Perl, PHP or Python module I need, and it'll usually update smoothly and
autmatically.  When I can't, I can generate an RPM or DEB package
directly from CPAN or whatever, which gives me some of the advantages of
a packaged module.

Of course, I am biased by my inexperience; I haven't used Slackware,
Gentoo or any of the BSDs.

business; however, this does not seem to be my experience. Are there  
others that have this experience?

From drl at drloree.com  Wed May 30 22:00:30 2007
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Wed, 30 May 2007 22:00:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] LAMP Platform Updating Problems
In-Reply-To: <C94E0348-837D-4C4D-A70B-0B4B3D169004@scottshill.com>
References: <C94E0348-837D-4C4D-A70B-0B4B3D169004@scottshill.com>
Message-ID: <1180587630.3644.76.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Wed, 2007-05-30 at 11:27 -0700, Kenneth B. Hill wrote:
> I have a been leading a development project of a database app that is  
> built on a LAMP-variant platform (it uses Gentoo Linux, Apache,  
> PostgreSQL AND PHP) along with some CPAN perl modules and MapServer.  
> We seem to have problems with updates to the individual LAMP tools  
> not working with the other LAMP tools. For example, if we update  
> Apache with a security update, then we experience with features in  
> the app not working in a perl mod or PHP etc.
> 
> I recently got back from a business trip, and I sat next to someone  
> on the airplane that does LAMP database application development. I  
> shared with him this experience, and he agreed with me that this is  
> an underlying problem with developing in a LAMP environment/platform.  
> This results in increasing our labor/time costs in maintaining the  
> infrastructure of the application. I would like to hear other  
> experiences with this issue - if any.

I have found that there are two distinct types of problems.  One is
caused by the Linux distribution package maintainers, the other is
caused by the program/language developers.  The changes in packages are
usually the settings used to compile the packages (this can lead to
dependency changes).  These can usually be solved by downloading the
package source and re-making the package (or download the program source
and recompile the program).  This can lead to a DIY Linux system, which
has its own benefits and drawbacks.

The developers of programs/languages have varying attitudes about
backward compatibility.  The range is from "we don't care" to "we will,
at all cost, maintain backward compatibility".

It may be easier to look at the likely problems with the different
parts.

I've never had a problem updating database servers, though I have read
about them.  PostgreSQL does an extremely good job of maintaining
backward compatibility.  MySQL tries hard, but has a higher problem
rate.

Apache does a very good job of maintaining backward compatibility,
though they did make sacrifices to create a better product --
particularly in the jump to Apache2.  The problems that do arise are
usually caused by the linux distribution's change in features that are
compiled in by default.  This is the most likely reason to go to a DIY
system.

PERL is somewhere between MySQL and Apache.  If you use strictly
pre-packaged modules, you should be OK; however, there are a lot of
chefs stirring this pot, so YMMV.   Thoroughly test your own code before
upgrading.

PHP is a version nightmare.  They really don't make any attempt to
maintain backward compatibility, the compatibility that is there is only
because the PHP developers couldn't find an excuse to change it.
Distributions like Debian and RH are essential for maintaining pre-built
packages (including libraries) and the version dependencies.  For your
own code, lots and lots of testing is required before attempting an
upgrade.  Better yet, start from scratch with the new version.  Code
that is written for multiple versions is BLOATED because of this
attitude. 

Some people just don't upgrade because of this.

Hope this helps.

-- 
Derek Loree

From plug_1 at robinson-west.com  Thu May 31 04:27:43 2007
From: plug_1 at robinson-west.com (someone)
Date: Thu, 31 May 2007 04:27:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Smart greylisting...
Message-ID: <20070531042743.bbq6euw6o04k8s0k@web.robinson-west.com>

Instead of blanket greylisting, I want to restrict when I graylist
by looking at who on my list of recipients a sender wants to reach.

I'm interested in smarter ways to use graylisting than the old
blanket approach.

It want to restrict graylisting to when something appears to be
wrong with the source.  Maybe it's a dynamically assigned ip
address, one that isn't registered in DNS databases at all, or
maybe the helo/ehlo is something suspicious.

I think what I'm talking about is having the outcome of
one smtp filtering policy impact or prevent the application
of another policy.

Say I have a relay recipients list like so:

foo at example.com           graylist
abuse at example.com         x
mail-list at example.com     x

bar at example2.com          x
abuse at example2.com        x
mail-list at example2.com    x

Looking at the above list, understand that the x means let it
through without graylisting it.  Understand also that mail to
example2.com should not be graylisted because that is a
friend's domain I am a backup relay for.  Slowing down his
legit customers on accident is unacceptable.  This example
is not real life, any relation to real life is purely
coincidental.

Does anyone maintain a decent list of which sources cannot be
graylisted?  Are there any secrets to knowing when graylisting
should not be used?

I am using postfix, but that only matters when I try to
implement something.

    --  Michael

> our Domain Controller to get the user automatically authenticated when they
> visit the site.
>

It might be easier to just use mod_auth_kerb.  I've seen this work
when authenticating
against an MIT KDC hosted on a unix box.  And I've heard that all you
have to do to get
it to authenticate against an AD server is to edit the config file.

Ali

From ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com  Thu May 31 09:38:02 2007
From: ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Thu, 31 May 2007 10:38:02 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux, Active Directory, and Samba
In-Reply-To: <d3acc08c0705310810v69be6d0apc9fc931d968d7b9a@mail.gmail.com>
References: <d3acc08c0705310810v69be6d0apc9fc931d968d7b9a@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <51853.127.0.0.1.1180629482.squirrel@webmail.pippiandcarlos.com>

> My Situation:
> Web developer with a non-Admin Windows account charged with creating an
> internal site that gives users the ability to automatically authenticate
> via
> their Windows Domain account.
>
> My Wish:
> I wish someone could help me figure out what I've done wrong or choose
> another, easier path for me to follow to reach my goal.  I'll now plop my
> config files below as well as any other pertinent information that I know
> about my problem.

I will take you up on your offer, and offer a different, easier solution. 
This is one I use at my job all the time.  If you were to do a packet
trace of an HTTP conversation in an AD environment, you would see that
there is always an NTLM-auth header in each request.  All you need is to
decode this header, and you'll have your NT username.

With this approach, your web server and webapps do not need to be
AD-aware, and you do not need samba, and you do not need any fancy apache
modules.  You just need to be able to read request headers in your
server-side code, and decode the BASE64 mess in the NTLM header.

Here's a java solution.  This is floating around on google in various
places.  I think it may have originated at sun.com.

Carlos Konstanski



public static String getUsernameFromAuthHeader(HttpServletRequest request,
                                               HttpServletResponse
response) {
    String authorizationHeader = request.getHeader("Authorization");
    if(authorizationHeader == null) {
        response.setStatus(HttpServletResponse.SC_UNAUTHORIZED);
        response.setHeader("WWW-Authenticate", "NTLM");
        return null;
    } else if(authorizationHeader.startsWith("NTLM ")) {
        byte[] ntlmBlock = null;
        try {
            ntlmBlock = new
BASE64Decoder().decodeBuffer(authorizationHeader.substring(5));
        } catch(IOException e) {
            return null;
        }
        int off = 0;
        int length;
        int offset;
        String rawUsername;
        if(ntlmBlock[8] == 3) {
            off = 30;
            length = ntlmBlock[off + 17] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off + 16];
            offset = ntlmBlock[off + 19] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off + 18];
            rawUsername = new String(ntlmBlock, offset, length);
        } else if(ntlmBlock[8] == 1) {
            off = 18;
            byte NULL = 0;
            byte[] responseBlock = { (byte)'N', (byte)'T', (byte)'L',
(byte)'M', (byte)'S', (byte)'S', (byte)'P', NULL, (byte)2,
NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, (byte)40, NULL,
NULL, NULL, (byte)1, (byte)130, NULL, NULL, NULL, (byte)2,
(byte)2, (byte)2, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL,
NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL };
            response.setStatus(HttpServletResponse.SC_UNAUTHORIZED);
            response.setHeader("WWW-Authenticate", "NTLM " + new
BASE64Encoder().encodeBuffer(responseBlock).trim());
            return null;
        } else {
            return null;
        }
        /* Still here? We have an NTLM username. */
        length = ntlmBlock[off + 1] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off];
        offset = ntlmBlock[off + 3] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off + 2];
        rawUsername = new String(ntlmBlock, offset, length);
        length = ntlmBlock[off + 9] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off + 8];
        offset = ntlmBlock[off + 11] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off + 10];
        rawUsername = new String(ntlmBlock, offset, length);
        /* Strip non-ASCII characters.  In linux/mozilla, for instance, we
get a NULL between every letter. */
        StringBuffer usernameBuffer = new StringBuffer("");
        byte[] usernameBytes = rawUsername.getBytes();
        for(int i = 0; i < usernameBytes.length; i++) {
            if(usernameBytes[i] >= 32 && usernameBytes[i] <= 127) {
                usernameBuffer.append((char)usernameBytes[i]);
            }
        }
        return usernameBuffer.toString();
    }
    return null;
}

On May 30, 2007, at 10:00 PM, Derek Loree wrote:

> On Wed, 2007-05-30 at 11:27 -0700, Kenneth B. Hill wrote:
>> I have a been leading a development project of a database app that is
>> built on a LAMP-variant platform (it uses Gentoo Linux, Apache,
>> PostgreSQL AND PHP) along with some CPAN perl modules and MapServer.
>> We seem to have problems with updates to the individual LAMP tools
>> not working with the other LAMP tools. For example, if we update
>> Apache with a security update, then we experience with features in
>> the app not working in a perl mod or PHP etc.
>>
>> I recently got back from a business trip, and I sat next to someone
>> on the airplane that does LAMP database application development. I
>> shared with him this experience, and he agreed with me that this is
>> an underlying problem with developing in a LAMP environment/platform.
>> This results in increasing our labor/time costs in maintaining the
>> infrastructure of the application. I would like to hear other
>> experiences with this issue - if any.
>
> I have found that there are two distinct types of problems.  One is
> caused by the Linux distribution package maintainers, the other is
> caused by the program/language developers.  The changes in packages  
> are
> usually the settings used to compile the packages (this can lead to
> dependency changes).  These can usually be solved by downloading the
> package source and re-making the package (or download the program  
> source
> and recompile the program).  This can lead to a DIY Linux system,  
> which
> has its own benefits and drawbacks.
>
> The developers of programs/languages have varying attitudes about
> backward compatibility.  The range is from "we don't care" to "we  
> will,
> at all cost, maintain backward compatibility".
>
> It may be easier to look at the likely problems with the different
> parts.
>
> I've never had a problem updating database servers, though I have read
> about them.  PostgreSQL does an extremely good job of maintaining
> backward compatibility.  MySQL tries hard, but has a higher problem
> rate.
>
> Apache does a very good job of maintaining backward compatibility,
> though they did make sacrifices to create a better product --
> particularly in the jump to Apache2.  The problems that do arise are
> usually caused by the linux distribution's change in features that are
> compiled in by default.  This is the most likely reason to go to a DIY
> system.
>
> PERL is somewhere between MySQL and Apache.  If you use strictly
> pre-packaged modules, you should be OK; however, there are a lot of
> chefs stirring this pot, so YMMV.   Thoroughly test your own code  
> before
> upgrading.
>
> PHP is a version nightmare.  They really don't make any attempt to
> maintain backward compatibility, the compatibility that is there is  
> only
> because the PHP developers couldn't find an excuse to change it.
> Distributions like Debian and RH are essential for maintaining pre- 
> built
> packages (including libraries) and the version dependencies.  For your
> own code, lots and lots of testing is required before attempting an
> upgrade.  Better yet, start from scratch with the new version.  Code
> that is written for multiple versions is BLOATED because of this
> attitude.
>
> Some people just don't upgrade because of this.
>
> Hope this helps.
>
> -- 
> Derek Loree
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

Derek,

I can confirm your comment about PHP being a version nightmare. When  
we test an update to PHP on a QA box/server and then deploy the  
update to the Production box/server, we still experience problems/new- 
bugs in the application. My development team refers to these problems  
as "regression bugs", and these "regression bugs" are what's driving  
up our operating costs (e.g., we perform a update to the LAMP tools,  
and the application we developed breaks). I don't have nearly as much  
of this problem with my Windows platform web applications. Maybe that  
is the trade-off with using LAMP versus Windows; one pays the license  
fee for the server OS, SQL Server database, IIS, etc. and one gets a  
little bit more reliable platform??? This has been a very interesting  
experience for me in realizing total ownership/operations cost (TOC)  
with open-source software.

-Ken

From jenred at gmail.com  Thu May 31 10:55:07 2007

Ken,

The problem is more likely with your choice of development software as
opposed to the Open Source Platform.  PHP is prolific these days, because it
"appears" to be easy to install and use for rapid development -- but the
thought of using in production still makes me shudder, primarily because of
security issues, and the constant need to update, because of those security
issues, and the very fact that the accessibility encourages sloppy
deployment.   You would probably be having fewer problems if you used Perl,
Python, or Ruby and one of the associated rapid development frameworks for
your application development.

Postgresql is enterprise-class as is the Apache HTTP server, (and I think
MySQL is starting to catch-up with Postgres).  Much more so then IIS and
SqlServer (that statement comes from years of experience running
highly-available large-scale web-applications in production on multiple
platforms).

Window's updates can cause just as many -- if not more application problems,
particularly if you are not using all of the prescribed MS software exactly
as you "should."  Most  Windows admins I know send out warnings and wait
until the building clears to run their updates, and still have stories about
regular weekend outages due to security updates.  Upgrading to a new version
takes months of planning and testing.  And if you want to just fix something
yourself -- it's impossible, you have to wait for Microsoft.  Sometimes you
want to implement new features -- but can't because you need to wait, once
again for Microsoft.  Plus, you have to schedule regular reboots.

There is no substitute for good process and planning in application
development -- this also applies to web, and infrastructure projects,
regardless of your platform.  There seems to be a tendency for people to
think that Open Source software is quick, easy and you don't have to follow
the rules, using PHP and maybe LAMP in general for development seems to
especially promote this line of thinking.

Also remember, you don't have to make all the recommended updates.  If
something is working and it's secure then don't move, unless there is a
major security problem and a new feature that you want to implement.

Before abandoning Open Source -- I highly recommend that you examine other
forces that may be leading to increased development costs.  And do another
requirements analysis.

Jen

> ? well exceeding my operations cost of my other Windows platform web
> applications. Much of this difference seems to be attributed to labor
> time on troubleshooting and debugging problems after an update was
> applied to one, or more, of the various LAMP tools.

>I started this LAMP application project 4+ years ago, because I  
>wanted to try and move my business away from the Windows platform  
>towards LAMP.

This depends on your situation Ken, but you have to look at the whole 
picture.

  Were you using php on windows?
  Were you running apache on windows?
  What was your development cost?
  How was the performance on the hardware?
  How was your (and your customers' data) security?
  How was your uptime?
  What was the licensing cost?
  Were you keeping up with your competitors' features?
  Why Gentoo?
  How is your test coverage?
  What is the bottom line?

If the bottom line is better on windows, sure.  If you're making more 
money running linux, but having trouble keeping current on the 
administration, look at outsourcing that to a local monitoring and 
maintenance crew.

My experience with Gentoo was that it required a lot of care and feeding 
vs a binary packaged distribution, particularly Debian.  Debian 
gracefully runs multiple versions of apache, etc.  There's some 
friction due to naming if you run into a source package that 
assumes /etc/apache/ or whatever, but they've done a really good job of 
keeping things straight.  If you're in a situation where you need to be 
building from source or otherwise running a special configuration, look 
at stow/xstow for managing multiple source-built versions.

I'm running 3 servers, 4 laptops, 2 workstations (and 5 nodes that only 
run distcc) on Debian (with an apt-proxy for speedier package pulls.)  
Sure, that takes more of my time than one windows box did 6 years ago, 
but none of my software has ever broken from "just plain usage" and the 
capabilities with Linux are way more than with windows, particularly 
when you start maintaining more than one box.  Uptime is great -- I 
never reboot anything unless upgrading the kernel.  But what really 
matters to me are the tools.

  bash, head, tail, grep, sed
  ln -s/stow
  gvim
  svn/svk
  ssh
  rsync/tar
  aptitude
  gcc/distcc
  perl/python
  apache
  imagemagick/pdftk/potrace
  gimp/inkscape

Sure you can run most of those on windows, but it really hurts.  You 
can't have symlinks though.

>When we test an update to PHP on a QA box/server and then deploy the  
>update to the Production box/server, we still experience problems/new- 
>bugs in the application.

I would recommend assessing that situation.  If your devs each run linux 
with a full stack on their workstation, plus you have a staging/ 
failover server before you hit the production box, that's a much better 
situation and likely to yield gains in many areas besides smoothing the 
upgrade cycle.

If you've got two boxen and you still see problems when you deploy, 
there's something missing in that process.  You have to bring the QA 
box to exactly the point where production box will be.  Consider making 
them interchangeable to the point where you can flip a switch to deploy 
a fully-tested server and then bring the downed box up to current.  
This might require separating your database server (and maybe 
templates+code) onto a third box, but that all depends on your 
availability requirements.

What does your deployment script look like?  How about the failover 
process?  Does a computer call somebody's pager when a box goes down?

Further, if you're not using a large number of the aforementioned tools 
throughout the development/deployment/monitoring process, you're really 
missing out on a lot of potential productivity and quality gain.  Also 
see:  test coverage.

E.g.  I'm building dotReader (http://dotreader.com) -- a 
Windows/Mac/Linux GUI application.  All of my development and most of 
my build, testing, and deployment automation happens on Linux because 
it is more efficient that way.  On the windows build box, I run cygwin 
because otherwise I would spend all of my time operating a mouse and 
couldn't automate anything remotely.  Compiling source code on windows 
is still painful.  Bugs directly attributable to the fact that it is 
still entirely based on a 22-year-old's port of CP/M don't help either.

The "you get what you pay for" is still true in open source.  The 
difference is that you can pay for it in either time or money.  
Similarly, you have a lot of options (hint: of the three that start 
with P, the best ends in "erl".)

I haven't dealt with many PHP upgrades, but I've read a lot of PHP code 
and can say "rigor" is never a term that came to mind.  The language 
just doesn't support anything remotely resembling engineering or 
security discipline -- it was all thrown out in favor of ease of 
learning.  Perl on the other hand, has a long history of performance, 
security-mindedness and careful integration plus power, usefulness,
and the fairly-recent addition of a strong "test,test,test" attitude to 
the culture.  CPAN may not be vetted, but it is *huge* and there is a 
lot of well-thought-out infrastructure to support testing, bug 
tracking, upgrades, etc.  See also:  "waterbed theory of complexity."

"What works for you" of course applies.  Remember though that the tools 
and processes associated with *nix (and its culture) have a long 
history of hard-won experience and careful thought.

And, as always, "if it hurts, you're doing it wrong."  If you (and your 
team) have read "The Art of Unix Programming" and everything I've said 
here is old-hat and you've gone through checking all of the boxes and 
running all of the numbers and windows is a better choice then so be 
it.

--Eric
-- 
[...proprietary software is better than gpl because...] "There is value
in having somebody you can write checks to, and they fix bugs."
--Mike McNamara (president of a commercial software company)

Open Source

[image: Hawk]*Building a Data Warehouse with MySQL and Perl
*<http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/databases/2007/04/12/building-a-data-warehouse-with-mysql-and-perl.html>
Most of us are at least somewhat familiar with the kind of relational
database schemas that are created for e-commerce sites, among others. But
there's another kind of database model out there: the data warehouse. Sam
Tregar gives us the lowdown on this highly UNrelational database.

*OpenBSD 4.1: Puffy Strikes
Again*<http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/bsd/2007/05/03/openbsd-41-puffy-strikes-again.html>
OpenBSD 4.1 has recently been released. It includes improvements to spam
fighting, SMP, porting to new platforms, and much more. As usual, Federico
Biancuzzi has sought out some of the most influential OpenBSD developers for
a discussion of what you'll find in 4.1

*Five Ways to Improve Your Perl Programming
*<http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/onlamp/2007/04/12/five-ways-to-improve-your-perl-programming.html>
Inside every tangle of obfuscated Perl code is a clean, well-architected gem
struggling to emerge from its cocoon. brian d foy has spent a lot of time
thinking about this for his new book, "Mastering Perl," and has come up with
a Top Five list of things that every Perl programmer should be thinking
about when writing code.

Sys Admin

[image: sunflower]*Top 7 Things System Administrators Forget to
Do*<http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/sysadmin/2007/05/03/the-top-7-things-sysadmins-forget-to-do.html>
Do system administrators really forget to do basic tasks because they're
lazy or do the pressures of the job keep them from getting everything done?
Tom Adelstein explores the top seven tasks system administrators forget to
do.

*Five Basic Mistakes Not to Make in
DNS*<http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/sysadmin/2007/04/26/5-basic-mistakes-not-to-make-in-dns.html>
DNS has managed to keep the Internet afloat for decades, but it spend a lot
of its time handling junk requests that should never have escaped from a
local WAN. Ron Aitchison has a list of five basic things that every DNS
administrator should take care of to keep DNS a happy infrastructure.

Digital Media

[image: lizard]*Rick LePage on Fine Art Printers for
Aperture*<http://digitalmedia.oreilly.com/2007/04/30/fine-art-printers-for-aperture.html>
Affordable hardware for fine art printing is more bountiful than ever. In
this exclusive Inside Aperture podcast, Macworld editor at large, Rick
LePage, covers the latest offerings from Epson, HP, and Canon. Rick supplies
plenty of insight about how HP is challenging Epson, and some thoughts about

*Review: Boss Micro BR Palmtop Recording

can use anywhere. It records up to 32 tracks, has a built-in mic and drum
machine, and even plays your MP3s. Can it possibly work at just $229 street?
Reviewer Gina Fant-Saez finds out.

From jmskinner at gmail.com  Thu May 31 14:50:43 2007

	<51853.127.0.0.1.1180629482.squirrel@webmail.pippiandcarlos.com>
Message-ID: <d3acc08c0705311450m3eccb830l35c3ff3f25844984@mail.gmail.com>

Thanks Carlos,

I've implemented this solution using PHP and I'm wondering if this is
secure.  Your solution depends on making sure the user agent sends the
windows authorization information with the http request.  If the user uses
mozilla or has the Logon option turned off of Internet Explorer, they will
be prompted for a username/password.  At this point they can enter any
information they want and it will grab whatever they input and store it.

Am I missing something?  Do I perhaps need something in an .htaccess file
for the directory I'm wishing to authenticate?

Thanks,
Josh

On 5/31/07, Carlos Konstanski <ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com> wrote:
>
> > My Situation:
> > Web developer with a non-Admin Windows account charged with creating an
> > internal site that gives users the ability to automatically authenticate
> > via
> > their Windows Domain account.
> >
> > My Wish:
> > I wish someone could help me figure out what I've done wrong or choose
> > another, easier path for me to follow to reach my goal.  I'll now plop
> my
> > config files below as well as any other pertinent information that I
> know
> > about my problem.
>
> I will take you up on your offer, and offer a different, easier solution.
> This is one I use at my job all the time.  If you were to do a packet
> trace of an HTTP conversation in an AD environment, you would see that
> there is always an NTLM-auth header in each request.  All you need is to
> decode this header, and you'll have your NT username.
>
> With this approach, your web server and webapps do not need to be
> AD-aware, and you do not need samba, and you do not need any fancy apache
> modules.  You just need to be able to read request headers in your
> server-side code, and decode the BASE64 mess in the NTLM header.
>
> Here's a java solution.  This is floating around on google in various
> places.  I think it may have originated at sun.com.
>
> Carlos Konstanski
>
>
>
> public static String getUsernameFromAuthHeader(HttpServletRequest request,
>                                                HttpServletResponse
> response) {
>     String authorizationHeader = request.getHeader("Authorization");
>     if(authorizationHeader == null) {
>         response.setStatus(HttpServletResponse.SC_UNAUTHORIZED);
>         response.setHeader("WWW-Authenticate", "NTLM");
>         return null;
>     } else if(authorizationHeader.startsWith("NTLM ")) {
>         byte[] ntlmBlock = null;
>         try {
>             ntlmBlock = new
> BASE64Decoder().decodeBuffer(authorizationHeader.substring(5));
>         } catch(IOException e) {
>             return null;
>         }
>         int off = 0;
>         int length;
>         int offset;
>         String rawUsername;
>         if(ntlmBlock[8] == 3) {
>             off = 30;
>             length = ntlmBlock[off + 17] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off + 16];
>             offset = ntlmBlock[off + 19] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off + 18];
>             rawUsername = new String(ntlmBlock, offset, length);
>         } else if(ntlmBlock[8] == 1) {
>             off = 18;
>             byte NULL = 0;
>             byte[] responseBlock = { (byte)'N', (byte)'T', (byte)'L',
> (byte)'M', (byte)'S', (byte)'S', (byte)'P', NULL, (byte)2,
> NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, (byte)40, NULL,
> NULL, NULL, (byte)1, (byte)130, NULL, NULL, NULL, (byte)2,
> (byte)2, (byte)2, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL,
> NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL };
>             response.setStatus(HttpServletResponse.SC_UNAUTHORIZED);
>             response.setHeader("WWW-Authenticate", "NTLM " + new
> BASE64Encoder().encodeBuffer(responseBlock).trim());
>             return null;
>         } else {
>             return null;
>         }
>         /* Still here? We have an NTLM username. */
>         length = ntlmBlock[off + 1] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off];
>         offset = ntlmBlock[off + 3] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off + 2];
>         rawUsername = new String(ntlmBlock, offset, length);
>         length = ntlmBlock[off + 9] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off + 8];
>         offset = ntlmBlock[off + 11] * 256 + ntlmBlock[off + 10];
>         rawUsername = new String(ntlmBlock, offset, length);
>         /* Strip non-ASCII characters.  In linux/mozilla, for instance, we
> get a NULL between every letter. */
>         StringBuffer usernameBuffer = new StringBuffer("");
>         byte[] usernameBytes = rawUsername.getBytes();
>         for(int i = 0; i < usernameBytes.length; i++) {
>             if(usernameBytes[i] >= 32 && usernameBytes[i] <= 127) {
>                 usernameBuffer.append((char)usernameBytes[i]);
>             }
>         }
>         return usernameBuffer.toString();
>     }
>     return null;
> }
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

From ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com  Thu May 31 15:42:14 2007
From: ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Thu, 31 May 2007 16:42:14 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux, Active Directory, and Samba
In-Reply-To: <d3acc08c0705311450m3eccb830l35c3ff3f25844984@mail.gmail.com>
References: <d3acc08c0705310810v69be6d0apc9fc931d968d7b9a@mail.gmail.com>
	<51853.127.0.0.1.1180629482.squirrel@webmail.pippiandcarlos.com>
	<d3acc08c0705311450m3eccb830l35c3ff3f25844984@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <55991.127.0.0.1.1180651334.squirrel@webmail.pippiandcarlos.com>

> Thanks Carlos,
>
> I've implemented this solution using PHP and I'm wondering if this is
> secure.  Your solution depends on making sure the user agent sends the
> windows authorization information with the http request.  If the user uses
> mozilla or has the Logon option turned off of Internet Explorer, they will
> be prompted for a username/password.  At this point they can enter any
> information they want and it will grab whatever they input and store it.
>
> Am I missing something?  Do I perhaps need something in an .htaccess file
> for the directory I'm wishing to authenticate?

You're not missing anything.  You should get the popup authentication
dialog box in non-IE browsers.  A user could enter anything they want in
the box.  Whether this is acceptable depends upon your level of security
need.  In an office like mine, where most people have their passwords
taped to the bottom of their keyboards, and managers have their
secretaries log onto the network and into ERP as them to do their work,
it's not such a big deal.  My company decided that they want to be secure
from external threats, but we trust our employees well enough.  The only
info we hide from employees is payroll information.  We're located in
Hailey, ID, which is a very honest place.  I haven't used my bike lock
since moving here from Eugene, and I don't even know if I am in possession
of a key for my house!  Security paranoia is not my strong suit.

You could always hand the username/password to an ASP or .NET script
running on an IIS server.  This would let you use native Windows tools to
validate the username/password against AD.  This is not as good as
kerberos, of course, because there is no ticket, and no 5 minute window. 
If you do this, you don't want to pass the username and password in the
request.  I always insert the username/password into a table, using the
sessionid as a unique key.  I pass only the sessionid to the next page. 
The next page looks up the username/password from the table with this key.
 This makes it impossible to find out a username/password by sniffing the
web traffic.

If your enterprise has an authenticating web proxy, the user will have to
use valid credentials to authenticate to it when they make their first
page request.  This will set the NTLM header with valid data.  By the time
they get to your page, they will have already been through this step, and
the NTLM header will be valid.

Even in IE, a hacker could forge the NTLM header.  As you can see
yourself, it is not encrypted, merely obfuscated.  If this is not secure
enough, do not use my method.
